On Mon, Jan 12, 2015 at 11:39 AM, Abhijit Kumbhare <abhijitkoss at gmail.com>
wrote:

Hello:

If you are on this list your project has yet to begin migrating to the
releng silo and Jenkins Job Builder (JJB).

At the time of this writing we now have 21 projects in the releng Jenkins
silo.  Overall, it will be very beneficial to all projects within
OpenDaylight to have every project under the releng Jenkins silo as
development and testing for Lithium ramp up.  For example, as it stands
right now, if your project has an integration job that is fired when an
upstream job is run, those jobs are no longer launching if your upstream
project has migrated to JJB (and many of the upstream projects such as
yangtools and controller already have).

There is a work-around short term if you really need those integration jobs
to fire before you migrate to the releng Jenkins silo, but the best long
term answer will be to just make the move as soon as your project is able.

The migration process is pretty straightforward and is documented here:
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/RelEng:Main#Builder

.. and as always, I'm very happy to help out if you have questions or get
stuck.

Thanks,

Thanh

Hi All,

I see interesting conversation here on the services being separated from Openflow.
Thought my experience may add some value to this discussion.
I was new to ODL and checked stub, SNMP4SDN and OpenFlow plugins and wrote a new custom plugin for a circuit switch where I reused the following services -
?  forwardingrules-manager
?  inventory-manager
?  topology-manager
I could use topology and inventory manager very well. I just used few parameters (which are relevant to our flows) for flows addition and deletion in forwardingrules-manager.
I could not use statistics manager service as the statistics are specific to packet switches and hence added a new REST API in this for circuit statistics.
I could not represent some properties for the nodeConnector but compromised them for an immediate solution.
Basically I tried reducing my work and hence reused the existing services.
So, I could make it work just by writing  a new southbound plugin without touching the services and the northbound.

It may be better to have the inventory and topology manager services available for any southbound plugin and not specific to openflow. Also, may be useful to make these more generic.
Also, Good to have the forwardingrules-manager services to be generic. So, one can add ACLs or Circuit connections or any other forwarding using this service.

Just my thoughts.
Correct me if I am wrong in any of the above.

Thanks,
Aneesha

On the one hand, I agree that the FRM is currently very OF-oriented, the idea that some of what we were calling "Network Service Functions" end up getting migrated to being inside a specific plugin does feel wrong.

As long as the parts that can be kept OF-independent can still be consumed and reimplemented by others, I guess it's fine to move them from the controller to the OpenFlow plugin project, but it does feel off.

On Thursday, January 8, 2015, Robert Varga -X (rovarga - Pantheon Technologies SRO at Cisco) <rovarga at cisco.com<mailto:rovarga at cisco.com>> wrote:
Hello Raghu,

I am a bit worried about ?protocol-agnostic? bit, as even if you factor the control protocol out, you have to make assumptions about your model of the world (contrast OF vs. PCEP vs. SR). Generic applications can work only as long as those assumptions hold.

FRM is very much OF-specific, as it has the notion of a ?flow?, at least now. Given where we are on the Lithium trajectory, we can only do so much.

Inventory-manager is completely tied to OF, and the OFP design calls for its complete integration into the OFP pipeline. Realistically, its functionality is tightly coupled with the lifecycle of the underlying protocol (we have fully-integrated equivalents in PCEP and NETCONF, and they work better). With the intetion to deprecate opendaylight-inventory model, the roles of inventory-manager and topology-manager are largely the same (when we disregard the discovery piece, which again is technology-specific).

Bye,
Robert

Subject: [L2switch-dev] migration of openflow related modules and applications from controller into ofplugin repo

Greetings,
there are already some activities going on which are aimed to migrate openflow related models and applications from controller to openflowplugin repository.

Migration will take following steps:

  *   copy corresponding projects from controller into openflowplugin
  *   change project and package names where necessary (without changing model content) (deadline: 09.01.2015)
  *   adapt downstream project in order to use those model projects (deadline: 16.01.2015)
  *   remove models from controller repository (deadline: 23.01.2015)

Models to migrate:

  *   model/model-flow-base
  *   model/model-flow-service
  *   model/model-flow-statistics

Apps to migrate

  *   statistics-manager
  *   forwardingrules-manager
  *   inventory-manager
  *   topology-lldp-discovery
  *   topology-manager

Donwstream projects (so far)

  *   aaa
  *   l2switch
  *   ovsdb
  *   openflowplugin
  *   affinity
  *   packetcable
  *   grupbasedpolicy

If you have questions, contributions, comments then please feel free to respond.

The reason for models to move into openflowplugin is that those models are openflow specific and mostly driven by openflowplugin development. And controller project plans to go more abstract/general way.

With applications the situation is similar with one difference - there is no direct downstream project, there are just projects depending on dataStore result of those applications.



There are no deadlines for applications yet but moving them together with models might spare us some renaming work.



Thank you.

Regards,

Michal

Subject: Re: [controller-dev] [openflowplugin-dev] [L2switch-dev] migration of openflow related modules and applications from controller into ofplugin repo

Few questions wanted to confirm with you:

1. Are you planning to upstream your custom plugin for circuit switching to OpenDaylight?
      Our Plugin does not really cover all the features of the Circuit Switch Specification. It has the functionality which is required for our switch. Does this partial implementation really add value if we upstream (and also using AD-SAL)?
2. Are you using the MD-SAL based OpenFlow implementation (plugin & FRM) or are you using the AD-SAL based OpenFlow implementation (the OpenFlow 1.0 protocol plugin, FRM, etc.)?
        We decided to go with Hydrogen Release and AD-SAL as Helium was still not released. We used the ?Extensions to the OpenFlow Protocol in support of Circuit Switching? (Addendum to OpenFlow Protocol Specification (v1.0) ? Circuit Switch Addendum v0.3). We would like to move to MD-SAL based OpenFlow implementation but with the current priority work items, it may take some time to do this. We still have no time frame for that.
3. Can you elaborate the rough design that you are using the FRM? Will be great if you can share an architecture diagram.
       The design is same as the Openflow protocol. I am sharing the user guide to get an idea on how I am using the FRM.

Subject: Re: [controller-dev] [openflowplugin-dev] [L2switch-dev] migration of openflow related modules and applications from controller into ofplugin repo

+1 to what Abhijit says above, but I'll add the caveat that if it ends up in the OF-plugin, it should be housed in such a way that it tries as best it can to avoid being any more OpenFlow-specific than it already is. Also, it should be amenable to other plugins providing the backing functionality.
For example, it should be possible and easy for somebody else to provide statistics and topology information to the relevant manager.

--Colin

On Mon, Jan 12, 2015 at 11:39 AM, Abhijit Kumbhare <abhijitkoss at gmail.com<mailto:abhijitkoss at gmail.com>> wrote:
Adding the controller-dev to this thread as well. To expand on what Michal alluded to about my thought regarding the OF-specific apps: it is possible for some one to use the OF-plugin but not use the L2 switch. So it should not be mandatory for them to need to include the L2 switch. By OF-specific apps (just so no one is confused) - Michal means what many people call NSFs:

?  statistics-manager
?  forwardingrules-manager
?  inventory-manager
?  topology-lldp-discovery
?  topology-manager
So I think these should be either in the controller, OF-plugin or a separate new place (but not L2 switch).


On Mon, Jan 12, 2015 at 11:24 AM, Michal Rehak -X (mirehak - Pantheon Technologies SRO at Cisco) <mirehak at cisco.com<mailto:mirehak at cisco.com>> wrote:
Hi Colin,
there was already discussion about renaming those apps so we do not block some good general name (like NSF).
And yes - we might later come up with some more general modeling here which would be shareable by multiple protocols or at least apps. And then we would definitely play with the idea of pulling those models up to separate project so that controller models will stay protocol agnostic.

Now Abhijit got this idea regarding where is the best place to move OF-specific apps:
Those apps depend on ofplugin but it seems they do not depend on l2switch. Are there any dependencies of those apps pointing on l2switch services?


Regards,
Michal

Sent: Monday, January 12, 2015 19:47

Cc: Raghurama Bhat; Michal Rehak -X (mirehak - Pantheon Technologies SRO at Cisco); release at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:release at lists.opendaylight.org>; openflowplugin-dev; Moiz Raja (moraja); aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>; ovsdb-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:ovsdb-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>; groupbasedpolicy-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:groupbasedpolicy-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>; affinity-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:affinity-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>; Jan Medved (jmedved); Ed Warnicke (eaw); l2switch-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:l2switch-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>

Subject: Re: [L2switch-dev] migration of openflow related modules and applications from controller into ofplugin repo

On the one hand, I agree that the FRM is currently very OF-oriented, the idea that some of what we were calling "Network Service Functions" end up getting migrated to being inside a specific plugin does feel wrong.

As long as the parts that can be kept OF-independent can still be consumed and reimplemented by others, I guess it's fine to move them from the controller to the OpenFlow plugin project, but it does feel off.

--Colin

On Thursday, January 8, 2015, Robert Varga -X (rovarga - Pantheon Technologies SRO at Cisco) <rovarga at cisco.com<mailto:rovarga at cisco.com>> wrote:
Hello Raghu,

I am a bit worried about ?protocol-agnostic? bit, as even if you factor the control protocol out, you have to make assumptions about your model of the world (contrast OF vs. PCEP vs. SR). Generic applications can work only as long as those assumptions hold.

FRM is very much OF-specific, as it has the notion of a ?flow?, at least now. Given where we are on the Lithium trajectory, we can only do so much.

Inventory-manager is completely tied to OF, and the OFP design calls for its complete integration into the OFP pipeline. Realistically, its functionality is tightly coupled with the lifecycle of the underlying protocol (we have fully-integrated equivalents in PCEP and NETCONF, and they work better). With the intetion to deprecate opendaylight-inventory model, the roles of inventory-manager and topology-manager are largely the same (when we disregard the discovery piece, which again is technology-specific).

Bye,
Robert

Hi,

Some of these make complete sense to me. For example, All the Openflow related models and OpenFlow specific components like Statistics Manager, and LLDP Discovery certainly belong in the Openflow Plugin project.

Thanks,

Subject: [L2switch-dev] migration of openflow related modules and applications from controller into ofplugin repo

Greetings,
there are already some activities going on which are aimed to migrate openflow related models and applications from controller to openflowplugin repository.

Migration will take following steps:

  *   copy corresponding projects from controller into openflowplugin
  *   change project and package names where necessary (without changing model content) (deadline: 09.01.2015)
  *   adapt downstream project in order to use those model projects (deadline: 16.01.2015)
  *   remove models from controller repository (deadline: 23.01.2015)

Models to migrate:

  *   model/model-flow-base
  *   model/model-flow-service
  *   model/model-flow-statistics

Apps to migrate

  *   statistics-manager
  *   forwardingrules-manager
  *   inventory-manager
  *   topology-lldp-discovery
  *   topology-manager

Donwstream projects (so far)

  *   aaa
  *   l2switch
  *   ovsdb
  *   openflowplugin
  *   affinity
  *   packetcable
  *   grupbasedpolicy

If you have questions, contributions, comments then please feel free to respond.

The reason for models to move into openflowplugin is that those models are openflow specific and mostly driven by openflowplugin development. And controller project plans to go more abstract/general way.

With applications the situation is similar with one difference - there is no direct downstream project, there are just projects depending on dataStore result of those applications.



There are no deadlines for applications yet but moving them together with models might spare us some renaming work.



Thank you.

Regards,

Michal

From: mirehak at cisco.com (Michal Rehak -X (mirehak - Pantheon Technologies SRO at Cisco))
Text:
Greetings,
here is the update of goals and deadlines:

With Amit from l2switch we came to agreement that all NSF apps will be moved to openflowplugin. And we might later change mind and move it elsewhere but for now in order not to increase current delay we want proceed.

Here are shifted deadlines for migration steps:

  *   copy corresponding projects from controller into openflowplugin
  *   change project and package names where necessary (without changing model content) (deadline: 16.01.2015)
  *   adapt downstream project in order to use those model projects (deadline: 23.01.2015)
  *   remove models from controller repository (deadline: 30.01.2015)

Regards,
Michal

Yeah. I agree 100%. Right now, the only way I know to do this is to undo

finer grain than all or nothing to the whole data store. That combined with

On Tue, Jan 20, 2015 at 6:26 AM, Khaldoon Al Zoubi <
khaldoon.alzoubi at huawei.com> wrote:

So, having a commit handler would really be the ideal solution, but I've
hard very little from anyone about implementing this.

Tony, Robert, TomP, any ideas on when/if we could expect a way for
applications to take part in the commit handling so that we can implement
these features. A *lot* of people are asking.

--Colin


On Tue, Jan 20, 2015 at 11:46 AM, Reinaldo Penno <rapenno at gmail.com> wrote:

AAA will not solve this.  The issue is business logic. Applications need to
apply specific constraints that is very specific to its business logic.

The ?RPC + AAA? might become the answer if it is the only answer, i.e.,
nobody fixes the bug.  Having RPCs is major hindrance and bring lots of
baggage to any Yang model that could certainly live without them.  Having
simple RESTconf URIs is infinitely easier to understand and manage.



From:  Colin Dixon <colin at colindixon.com>
Date:  Tuesday, January 20, 2015 at 11:33 AM
To:  Khaldoon Al Zoubi <khaldoon.alzoubi at huawei.com>
Cc:  "controller-dev at lists.opendaylight.org"
<controller-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>, "aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org"
<aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject:  Re: [controller-dev] RestConf API Operations

Yeah. I agree 100%. Right now, the only way I know to do this is to undo the
operations that you didn't want to happen.

I know that AAA was looking into better access control to the MD-SAL at a
finer grain than all or nothing to the whole data store. That combined with
RPCs to allow for certain known access paths is probably the eventually
correct answer.

--Colin


On Tue, Jan 20, 2015 at 6:26 AM, Khaldoon Al Zoubi
<khaldoon.alzoubi at huawei.com> wrote:

https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1435

It is targeted for Lithium. While it will be immediately useful for 
applications, we also need a configurable generic AAA component, as 
hand-coding these handlers for each application will be prone to errors. 
One very specific concern is that the commit cohorts must refrain from 
leaking state outside the datastore domain -- we have seen this in the 
Hydrogen release, where applications hooking onto this mechanism (which 
is very similar to DCL) brought the system down simply because they 
violated API contracts.

Bye,
Robert

Hello AAA team,

On Jan 12 I sent the following email about the need for a Security Credential Service.
https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/2015-January/000244.html

I'm working on two projects, DIDM and SNMP Plugin.  These projects need to interact with a device using SNMP.  Interacting with a device requires security credentials (eg, password, community name, etc.).  The credential service should allow the operator to populate the service with security credentials, and allow applications to acquire the security credentials managed by the Credential Server.  For the first release, this service can be fairly simple and we have been working on a prototype.

My question to the AAA team is about ownership.  Who should own this type of service?  Is this something that should be owned by the AAA team?  Is the AAA team interested in working with the SNMP Plugin team on this?  Who should I be discussion this with on the AAA team?

Thanks
Steve
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20150122/894b826a/attachment.html>

Hi Steve,

I see generic credential management to be part of the AAA project?s scope.  See the model here<https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1D2yIkSn-ZOURZhL-_hikw0F7VBnWdknL-pONAScSyZk/edit>.  These credentials may be used for either NB, SB, or even sideways communication.  However, the release plan for AAA for Lithium currently does not include a credential manager service (due to resource constraints).  If this is something you can contribute to AAA, that would be greatly welcome!  And, of course, we can work with you on it to make sure it fits into the current AAA framework.

Thanks,
Liem

From: <Dean>, Steve <sdean at hp.com<mailto:sdean at hp.com>>
Date: Thursday, January 22, 2015 at 8:35 AM
To: "aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>" <aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Cc: "snmp-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:snmp-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>" <snmp-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:snmp-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>>, "didm-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:didm-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>" <didm-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:didm-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>>
Subject: [Aaa-dev] Security Credential Service

Hello AAA team,

On Jan 12 I sent the following email about the need for a Security Credential Service.
https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/2015-January/000244.html

I?m working on two projects, DIDM and SNMP Plugin.  These projects need to interact with a device using SNMP.  Interacting with a device requires security credentials (eg, password, community name, etc.).  The credential service should allow the operator to populate the service with security credentials, and allow applications to acquire the security credentials managed by the Credential Server.  For the first release, this service can be fairly simple and we have been working on a prototype.

My question to the AAA team is about ownership.  Who should own this type of service?  Is this something that should be owned by the AAA team?  Is the AAA team interested in working with the SNMP Plugin team on this?  Who should I be discussion this with on the AAA team?

Thanks
Steve

Kyle,

Aaa authn can integrate with a wide variety of systems, of which keystone is but one.  This move doesn't force the issue, and I expect the existing http basic auth admin:admin to remain the default.

Liem (from the Aaa project) is probably the right guy to reach out to the keystone guts to understand their objection to that (one among many) aaa integration option(s).

Ed

Coincidentally, AAA (Lithium) can use Keystone as an IdP (and not the other way around).  That is, a token obtained from Keystone can be used to authenticate/authorize with the ODL controller.

Regards,
Liem

On Jan 26, 2015, at 7:32 PM, Kyle Mestery <mestery at mestery.com<mailto:mestery at mestery.com>> wrote:
On Mon, Jan 26, 2015 at 3:08 PM, Edward Warnicke <hagbard at gmail.com<mailto:hagbard at gmail.com>> wrote:
I have a patch here:

https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/13546/

that:
a)  Takes option #2 (moves adsal to port 8282, adds the stock jetty to port 8080)
b)  Makes sure that neutron works correctly with jetty.

I've tested it as noted in the commit comments, and would welcome others testing it as well.

If there are no issues, I'd like to merge it on 2/1/2015.

A few notes:
1)  It makes neutron use our aaa project authn, so we should (Liem will have to chime in to explain) get the ability to interface our neutron service with Keystone.

I was in some meetings with (among others) the PTL of Keystone, and this is NOT something the keystone folks want. Before you go down this path, I suggest talking to the keystone folks.

2)  Since there *wasn't* a neutron feature before you could load on its own, there is now a neutron feature, you can see how to use it in the patch for integration here:
https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/14524/

Since the previous way to pick up neutron was to pull in odl-nsf-all, you will need to change to using the old-neutron-northbound feature if you provide an existing provider.

Thoughts?

Ed

On Mon, Jan 19, 2015 at 5:23 AM, Anil Vishnoi <vishnoianil at gmail.com<mailto:vishnoianil at gmail.com>> wrote:
IMO, #2 is an ideal solution, but given that in community we think going forward AD-SAL will be deprecated so probably it make sense to defer to #1.

The only concern I see with #1 is that it will invite lot of questions like "it was working with hydrogen/helium but not working with current master" :) ( which i believe we can't avoid anyways) AND also updating the relevant documentation. If we can take care of documentation as well, I vote for #1.

Was there any discussion on when are we deprecating AD-SAL? AFAIK there were couple of discussions over mailing list but those never reached to any conclusion as such. IMHO having a time frame helps a lot to take decision about these kind of problems. e.g If we decide that AD-SAL deprecation will be announce in this release and it will be removed in beryllium, then IMO it probably make sense to defer the port change till next release.

Thanks
Anil

On Wed, Jan 14, 2015 at 6:10 AM, Mathieu Lemay <mlemay at inocybe.com<mailto:mlemay at inocybe.com>> wrote:
Hi Ed,

Indeed that has been problematic.  AD-SAL is using the Valves for security and is wielded from a user management perspective.However, I would like to see the community's opinion on the two options.

These options would be

#1 Leave everything as-is and simply move that to port 8282 to avoid confusion from people. Bringing AD-SAL would bring Tomcat. It also create a variety of 'Errors' in the logs as Jetty will also try to start the webapps and fail to do so because of the Tomcat-specific addons.

#2 Remove the Valves and Tomcat dependency and run AD-SAL alongside the current 8181 applications (on Jetty). This means that many northbound services will have to be revisited. While the task is not enormous it is more work than #1.. If people no longer use AD-SAL I'd vote for #1.. if there is a need for it I can look in #2.

Please let me know what you guys think!

Cheers
Mathieu

On Wed, Jan 14, 2015 at 7:55 AM, Edward Warnicke <hagbard at gmail.com<mailto:hagbard at gmail.com>> wrote:
Guys,

     The old AD-SAL stuff is currently running a completely separate (and antiquated) Tomcat based stack on port 8080.  Unfortunately there are pieces of the AD-SAL that are quite thoroughly welded to Tomcat, and cannot easily be extracted from it.
     All of the newer stuff is using the karaf build in jetty web stack, which is currently running on port 8181.
     Port 8080 is traditionally the port used for web stuff in the java world.

     As the AD-SAL is being deprecated, I'd like to move the AD-SAL stuff to using port 8282, and have the karaf built in jetty running on port 8080 and 8181.  (please note I already have a patch out for making the neutron service run with jetty, on which every ports it is running, so this change should *not* impact the neutron service stuff).

     Before pushing patches to do this, I wanted to open up a discussion to see what other folks think about it.  So please see this less as a notification and more as a conversation starter ;)

Ed

Hello,
I was asked to capture the events regarding an enhancement request I submitted to the AAA team.
The SNMP Plugin project is developing a plugin that allows application to interact with devices using SNMP.  Interacting with a device using SNMP requires a Security Credential.  On Jan 12 I filed an enhancement request in Bugzilla (#2576) and sent email to aaa-dev mailing list. https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/2015-January/000244.html
The request was asking the AAA team to provide a Security Credential Service to manage credentials.
On Jan 22 a response email was sent by Liem Nyugen stating that generic credential management is part of AAA's scope, but the release plan for Lithium does not include it due to resource constraints.  Liem stated the AAA team would welcome a contribution from the SNMP Plugin team, and that the AAA team would work with the SNMP Plugin team regarding a contribution from the SNMP team.

Going forward the SNMP Plugin team will work on the Security Credential Service and continue to work with the AAA team.



Thanks,

Steve

We have voted in a new PTL for AAA:  Wojciech Dec from Cisco!

Congrats, Wojciech!  It's well-deserved...  In case you don't know, Wojciech has been with us (AAA) since the project's inception and has been in-charge of all the authorization magic in the project.

Cheers,
Liem

PS:  I will be working with Wojciech to ensure a smooth transition...

Hi Folks,

on last weeks call the question of "how do we go about validating library
licenses" came up in the context of the Rest client discussion

The short answer is that, in general an Apache Commons, will be fine and
there is a background scan process in place to pick up any "imports".
The longer answer is that if anyone has particular concerns or wants a
proactive review, then please contact *probb at linuxfoundation.org
<probb at linuxfoundation.org>*.

Cheers,
Wojciech.

I am in the process of trying to get us in position to migrate to karaf
3.0.3... so far everything works fine with one exception:

feature odl-aaa-authn depends on:

<bundle>wrap:mvn:org.xerial/sqlite-jdbc/3.7.2</bundle>

and it no longer wraps correctly.  I suspect this is because of the JNI
hacks it uses
to be able to run sqllite (which is not java based), but do not actually
know yet (still poking).

What would it take to replace sqllite with something a little more
mainstream in the java world (like Apache Derby)?

Ed

P.S.  I am not having any other issues with 'wrapped' bundles other than
this so far, but with

Hi Taro,

it appears that the 3.8.7 sqlite wrap library is not compatible with Java
8. May I ask you if you're planning on providing an updated version any
time soon?

Thanks,
Wojciech.

I am in the process of trying to get us in position to migrate to karaf
3.0.3... so far everything works fine with one exception:

feature odl-aaa-authn depends on:

<bundle>wrap:mvn:org.xerial/sqlite-jdbc/3.7.2</bundle>

and it no longer wraps correctly.  I suspect this is because of the JNI
hacks it uses
to be able to run sqllite (which is not java based), but do not actually
know yet (still poking).

What would it take to replace sqllite with something a little more
mainstream in the java world (like Apache Derby)?

Ed

And if we  could please move to a non-sqlite jdbc provider so we don't hit

Java has an embarrassment of riches there...

On Thu, Feb 19, 2015 at 2:22 AM, Wojciech Dec <wdec.ietf at gmail.com> wrote:

Hi All,

just a reminder, bridge details have changed...

On 16 February 2015 at 16:11, Wojciech Dec (wdec) <wdec at cisco.com> wrote:

Hi All,

given the rotation of ocus areas as well as people on the AAA Project,
we've come to a situation where only a few of the original project's
committers and contributors are still actively participating. As such we
would like to call for new committer candidates.
If interested please do a reply to all to express your interest and
optionally provide an brief summary of:
- Your coding experience, esp in Java
- Examples, if any, of you contributions to the ODL project (esp AAA) or
other open-source projects

While the above info is optional, I'm sure it will likely help folks in
getting to know you and evaluating your candidature, especially if you're
new to the project

Your replies will go in for a short list out of which, following the
project's procedures, a set of committers will be chosen by the current
committers and the ODL TSC.

If interested, please reply by Wed, Feb 25.

Thanks,
Wojciech.
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20150220/519097ae/attachment.html>

Hi All,
I would like to nominate myself as a committer. I have over 21 years experience in design and coding large scale distributed systems, out of 15 years are in java.
I have contribute to ODL the xsql, which is a SQL & JDBC front end to the ODL data store and I have started to contribute to ODL around security with encrypting the config file systems and I have in the pipeline adding hash+SOLT to the AAA passwords.
I also have initiated the DataSand project in github, where it is designed to make it easy for applications running in different JVMs to communicate with each other and be queried as one virtual database via JDBC.

Sent from my Android phone using TouchDown (www.nitrodesk.com)

Hi Ed,

There is a AAA project deliverable for Lithium to stop using sqlite and switch to using the persistence project?s database solution.

From: discuss-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:discuss-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Edward Warnicke
Sent: Friday, February 20, 2015 5:52 AM
To: Jamie G.
Cc: discuss at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight Discuss] Migrating to karaf 3.0.3 and supporting Java 8

sqlite also has quite limited portability... and since we have folks trying to run ODL on all kinds of platforms... having that lack of portability at the heart of ODL is probably also not a good idea...

Ed

On Fri, Feb 20, 2015 at 5:05 AM, Jamie G. <jamie.goodyear at gmail.com<mailto:jamie.goodyear at gmail.com>> wrote:
First, report the bug to Pax URL, that way 2.3.1 could be fixed if possible:
https://ops4j1.jira.com/browse/PAXURL

Then raise an issue at Karaf to track the need to pick up the fix from
Pax URL project:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KARAF

If the issue can't be resolved in Pax URL 2.3.x line, then there is
always the option to make an update to ODL's controller distribution
to use the older Pax URL lib.

Cheers,
Jamie

On Fri, Feb 20, 2015 at 5:01 AM, Harmon, Nathan (HP Networking) <nathan.harmon at hp.com<mailto:nathan.harmon at hp.com>> wrote:

No.. because MySQL is not binary portable... we really really really need
to preserve binary portability (see the issues we've had with sqlite as
opposed to something like Derby or H2 which is binary portable).

I'd have not issue with folks having the *option* to back with MySQL, but
it would be a big problem for out of the box.

Ed

First, report the bug to Pax URL, that way 2.3.1 could be fixed if possible:
https://ops4j1.jira.com/browse/PAXURL

Then raise an issue at Karaf to track the need to pick up the fix from Pax URL project:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KARAF

If the issue can't be resolved in Pax URL 2.3.x line, then there is always the option to make an update to ODL's controller distribution to use the older Pax URL lib.

Cheers,
Jamie

Subject: Call for AAA committer candidates.

Hi All,
given the rotation of ocus areas as well as people on the AAA Project, we've come to a situation where only a few of the original project's committers and contributors are still actively participating. As such we would like to call for new committer candidates.
If interested please do a reply to all to express your interest and optionally provide an brief summary of:
- Your coding experience, esp in Java
- Examples, if any, of you contributions to the ODL project (esp AAA) or other open-source projects
While the above info is optional, I'm sure it will likely help folks in getting to know you and evaluating your candidature, especially if you're new to the project

Your replies will go in for a short list out of which, following the project's procedures, a set of committers will be chosen by the current committers and the ODL TSC.
If interested, please reply by Wed, Feb 25.
Thanks,
Wojciech.

Greetings,
here is update regarding migration:

  * aaa -> NOOP
 * l2switch -> DONE
    merged: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/14518
    https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=2647
 * ovsdb -> DONE
    merged: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/15643
    https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=2654
 * affinity -> INCOMPLETE
    pending: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/14572
 * packetcable -> INCOMPLETE
    pending: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/14576
    https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=2675
 * grupbasedpolicy -> DONE
    abandoned: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/14598 (used transient dependency to models)
 * sfc -> DONE
    merged: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/15657<https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/15657;>
    abandoned: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/14605
 * openflowplugin -> DONE
   https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=2611

After all downstream project are merged and confirmed working there is one last step - clean up models, features and apps in controller: https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=2751

Currently pending actions are only by projects AFFINITY and PACKETCABLE.

Michal

From: release-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [release-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] on behalf of Michal Rehak -X (mirehak - Pantheon Technologies SRO at Cisco)
Sent: Thursday, January 15, 2015 20:27
To: release at lists.opendaylight.org
Cc: openflowplugin-dev; aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; ovsdb-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; groupbasedpolicy-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; affinity-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; l2switch-dev at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [release] [openflowplugin-dev] migration of openflow related modules and applications from controller into ofplugin repo

Greetings,
here is the update of goals and deadlines:

With Amit from l2switch we came to agreement that all NSF apps will be moved to openflowplugin. And we might later change mind and move it elsewhere but for now in order not to increase current delay we want proceed.

Here are shifted deadlines for migration steps:

  *   copy corresponding projects from controller into openflowplugin
  *   change project and package names where necessary (without changing model content) (deadline: 16.01.2015)
  *   adapt downstream project in order to use those model projects (deadline: 23.01.2015)
  *   remove models from controller repository (deadline: 30.01.2015)

Regards,
Michal


________________________________
From: openflowplugin-dev-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [openflowplugin-dev-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] on behalf of Michal Rehak -X (mirehak - Pantheon Technologies SRO at Cisco)
Sent: Wednesday, January 07, 2015 17:09
To: release at lists.opendaylight.org
Cc: openflowplugin-dev; aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; ovsdb-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; groupbasedpolicy-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; affinity-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; l2switch-dev at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: [openflowplugin-dev] migration of openflow related modules and applications from controller into ofplugin repo

Greetings,
there are already some activities going on which are aimed to migrate openflow related models and applications from controller to openflowplugin repository.

Migration will take following steps:

  *   copy corresponding projects from controller into openflowplugin
  *   change project and package names where necessary (without changing model content) (deadline: 09.01.2015)
  *   adapt downstream project in order to use those model projects (deadline: 16.01.2015)
  *   remove models from controller repository (deadline: 23.01.2015)

Models to migrate:

  *   model/model-flow-base
  *   model/model-flow-service
  *   model/model-flow-statistics

Apps to migrate

  *   statistics-manager
  *   forwardingrules-manager
  *   inventory-manager
  *   topology-lldp-discovery
  *   topology-manager

Donwstream projects (so far)

  *   aaa
  *   l2switch
  *   ovsdb
  *   openflowplugin
  *   affinity
  *   packetcable
  *   grupbasedpolicy

If you have questions, contributions, comments then please feel free to respond.

The reason for models to move into openflowplugin is that those models are openflow specific and mostly driven by openflowplugin development. And controller project plans to go more abstract/general way.

With applications the situation is similar with one difference - there is no direct downstream project, there are just projects depending on dataStore result of those applications.


There are no deadlines for applications yet but moving them together with models might spare us some renaming work.


Thank you.

Regards,

Michal

URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20150224/ee1798d2/attachment.html>
Why is affinity in the list? this project was not in Helium and will not be in Lithium.

HI Wojciech,

I've pushed out an initial change to address your request for more negative testing (null, empty string, etc.) at https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/15688. This change was supposed to be targeted at only ClaimBuilder. However, since AuthenticationBuilder extends it, I had to make changes there as well. Unfortunately, there was no validation for these types of failures in place in the builders. So I ended up touching quite a few files already, and I'm not done yet. After speaking with Liem, there were a few issues that needed to be addressed:
1) missing validation (I've tried to update the interface documentation to capture at a minimum the required fields).
2) the MutableClaim and MutableAuthentication are actually supposed to be Immutable 

Also, in chatting with some folks here it sounds like these builders would actually go away, if we end up moving the authentication piece into MD-SAL, since they would be generated by the yang tools. 

So my question is with respect to the current commit I've posted. Is it the right direction to take? If we are going to move authn into MD-SAL, maybe we just skip hardening the builders for now?

  *   copy corresponding projects from controller into openflowplugin
  *   change project and package names where necessary (without changing model content) (deadline:16.01.2015)
  *   adapt downstream project in order to use those model projects (deadline: 23.01.2015)
  *   remove models from controller repository (deadline: 30.01.2015)

Regards,
Michal

From: openflowplugin-dev-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:openflowplugin-dev-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> [openflowplugin-dev-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:openflowplugin-dev-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org>] on behalf of Michal Rehak -X (mirehak - Pantheon Technologies SRO at Cisco)
Sent: Wednesday, January 07, 2015 17:09
To: release at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:release at lists.opendaylight.org>
Cc: openflowplugin-dev; aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; ovsdb-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; groupbasedpolicy-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; affinity-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; l2switch-dev at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: [openflowplugin-dev] migration of openflow related modules and applications from controller into ofplugin repo

Greetings,
there are already some activities going on which are aimed to migrate openflow related models and applications from controller to openflowplugin repository.

Migration will take following steps:

  *   copy corresponding projects from controller into openflowplugin
  *   change project and package names where necessary (without changing model content) (deadline:09.01.2015)
  *   adapt downstream project in order to use those model projects (deadline: 16.01.2015)
  *   remove models from controller repository (deadline: 23.01.2015)

Models to migrate:

  *   model/model-flow-base
  *   model/model-flow-service
  *   model/model-flow-statistics

Apps to migrate

  *   statistics-manager
  *   forwardingrules-manager
  *   inventory-manager
  *   topology-lldp-discovery
  *   topology-manager

Donwstream projects (so far)

  *   aaa
  *   l2switch
  *   ovsdb
  *   openflowplugin
  *   affinity
  *   packetcable
  *   grupbasedpolicy

If you have questions, contributions, comments then please feel free to respond.
The reason for models to move into openflowplugin is that those models are openflow specific and mostly driven by openflowplugin development. And controller project plans to go more abstract/general way.
With applications the situation is similar with one difference - there is no direct downstream project, there are just projects depending on dataStore result of those applications.

There are no deadlines for applications yet but moving them together with models might spare us some renaming work.

Thank you.
Regards,
Michal

On Wed, Feb 25, 2015 at 12:49 PM, Luis Gomez <ecelgp at gmail.com> wrote:

From: vrpolak at cisco.com (Vratko Polak -X (vrpolak - Pantheon Technologies SRO at Cisco))
Text:
Hi Luis.

As your TWS talk is nearing, I would like to present my views.

I think ${project}-integration job does basically the same thing
as ${project}-merge, only the triggers (and notifications) are different.
Build from source in ${project} git, run unit tests, upload artifacts.
*-merge is triggered by gerrit; *-integration should be triggered
by ${dependency}-merge and ${dependency}-integration jobs.
Maybe we should merge them to a single ${project}-publish job if possible.
For some reason I neglected this mail, see my answers in-line:

Hi Vrakto,

Thanks for your mail, see my answers in-line.

So the problem I see is the following:

1) a controller committer merges a patch
2) controller-merge-master publishes artifacts
3a) controller-distribution triggers
3b) openflowjava-integration-master triggers

Now we have two jobs running (3a, 3b) and based on the layout of job 
queue, slave spinup, etc. etc., three things can happen:
- 3a may pick up artifacts from 3b, or
- 3a picks up artifacts before 3b, or
- 3a picks up some artifacts before 3b and some after that

The same thing is going to happen if I quickly merge a bunch of patches...

Bye,
Robert

On 02/26/2015 06:56 PM, Luis Gomez wrote:
Hi Robert, see my comments in-line:
On 02/26/2015 07:53 PM, Luis Gomez wrote:

I am not sure I follow here, can you explain more:

1) false positives, from where?

2) high-impossible to track down, the only artifact that really changes is the controller artifact, is that so difficult to figure out?

BR/Luis

Note that I am not questioning the intent, but am worried about the 
results as-currently-implemented. It is very important to understand 
what artifacts will get into that distribution, since if that image will 
undergo CSIT to see whether a controller change did not break OF, that 
OF piece needs to be self-consistent.

Jenkins are just like threads, with Nexus being memory. What I am asking 
is: what are the locks the reader (controller-distribution job) holds to 
prevent writers (all the merge and integration jobs) from modifying 
state (artifacts in Nexus) as it is being read to assemble the distribution?

If we have no such assurances, what assurance do we have in the 
reliability and repeatability departments? When things break, how do we 
track which source code corresponds to that particular controller-build?

Thanks,
Robert

On 25 February 2015 at 02:06, Krell, Sherry <sherry.krell at hp.com<mailto:sherry.krell at hp.com>> wrote:
HI Wojciech,

I've pushed out an initial change to address your request for more negative testing (null, empty string, etc.) at https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/15688. This change was supposed to be targeted at only ClaimBuilder. However, since AuthenticationBuilder extends it, I had to make changes there as well. Unfortunately, there was no validation for these types of failures in place in the builders. So I ended up touching quite a few files already, and I'm not done yet. After speaking with Liem, there were a few issues that needed to be addressed:
1) missing validation (I've tried to update the interface documentation to capture at a minimum the required fields).
2) the MutableClaim and MutableAuthentication are actually supposed to be Immutable

Also, in chatting with some folks here it sounds like these builders would actually go away, if we end up moving the authentication piece into MD-SAL, since they would be generated by the yang tools.

So my question is with respect to the current commit I've posted. Is it the right direction to take? If we are going to move authn into MD-SAL, maybe we just skip hardening the builders for now?

On 25 February 2015 at 10:40, Wojciech Dec <wdec.ietf at gmail.com> wrote:

Hi Folks,

Following up on this. So the problem appears to be an internal race condition inside of MD-SAL / AAA / config system combined with logic flaws about retrying connections.

Basically, the way I get this to reproduce is Iist all of the features that I want to install in the featuresBoot list and then start a clean controller (I.e. delete data directory, delete /etc/opendaylight). When the controller starts up there is a race condition from the config subsystem injecting the self-referencing netconf connection and the AAA database being locked. When the problem occurs the AAA database file is locked and thus when netconf tries to connect and specifically authenticate the AAA fails because of an exception. Then because the config subsystem, or more specifically the netconf mounter is a try once and done (no retries) it fails to connect the self-referencing controller.

Potential fixes from what I can tell:


 1.  enhance AAA logic to handle issues when the database might be locked, and consider a wait retry mechanism (we would need to answer the question of ?when would we expect this error? to implement something like this).
 2.  and/or enhance the netconf mounting logic to retry even if it got a failed authentication (though that seems a little strange)

I think ultimately #1 is the longer term fix. If you are trying to reproduce this note that I see this every once in a while - on 10 machines, I see it consistently on 1 of them every time I run a suite of tests.

For now I have worked around this by installing the features more slowly / independently, but this is clearly not an ideal solution. I?ll see if I can?t come up with a more consistent reproduction scenario but figured I would share what I know in the mean time.

Pone other comment - in the AAA code it would be really helpful it the entire exception was printed to the log, not just the message. In general the AAA code catches exceptions and logs the e.getMessage() or they use an overloaded toString on the exception to only print a simple message. It is better practice to print the stack trace too though to make it easier to debug :)   log.info( ?Caught exception ? + e.getMessage(), e ) <? passing the exception as a second argument will print the stack trace to the log for the exception and may provide additional information.

Thank you,

Devin

Devin Avery
Devin.Avery at Brocade.com

On 10 March 2015 at 14:19, Devin Avery <davery at brocade.com<mailto:davery at brocade.com>> wrote:
Hi Folks,

Following up on this. So the problem appears to be an internal race condition inside of MD-SAL / AAA / config system combined with logic flaws about retrying connections.

Basically, the way I get this to reproduce is Iist all of the features that I want to install in the featuresBoot list and then start a clean controller (I.e. delete data directory, delete /etc/opendaylight). When the controller starts up there is a race condition from the config subsystem injecting the self-referencing netconf connection and the AAA database being locked. When the problem occurs the AAA database file is locked and thus when netconf tries to connect and specifically authenticate the AAA fails because of an exception. Then because the config subsystem, or more specifically the netconf mounter is a try once and done (no retries) it fails to connect the self-referencing controller.

Potential fixes from what I can tell:


 1.  enhance AAA logic to handle issues when the database might be locked, and consider a wait retry mechanism (we would need to answer the question of ?when would we expect this error? to implement something like this).
 2.  and/or enhance the netconf mounting logic to retry even if it got a failed authentication (though that seems a little strange)

I think ultimately #1 is the longer term fix. If you are trying to reproduce this note that I see this every once in a while - on 10 machines, I see it consistently on 1 of them every time I run a suite of tests.

For now I have worked around this by installing the features more slowly / independently, but this is clearly not an ideal solution. I?ll see if I can?t come up with a more consistent reproduction scenario but figured I would share what I know in the mean time.

Pone other comment - in the AAA code it would be really helpful it the entire exception was printed to the log, not just the message. In general the AAA code catches exceptions and logs the e.getMessage() or they use an overloaded toString on the exception to only print a simple message. It is better practice to print the stack trace too though to make it easier to debug :)   log.info<http://log.info>( ?Caught exception ? + e.getMessage(), e ) <? passing the exception as a second argument will print the stack trace to the log for the exception and may provide additional information.

Thank you,

Devin

Devin Avery
Devin.Avery at Brocade.com<mailto:Devin.Avery at Brocade.com>

update on the AAA M3 milestones:

Openstack Keystone federation- M3 milestone met karaf features submitted.

direct/client authentication tests (Robot framework)

To: controller-dev at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: [controller-dev] My DevStack integration borked .. AAA errors in log.

I tried to run my OpenStack GBP to OpenDaylight GBP integration last night.

DevStack throws "500 server errors?. This was working absolutely fine 9 days ago, (snapshot) and probably since then too (can?t recall last time I ran it, but pretty sure since 9 days ago, so can?t give you an exact date it worked last, but I know it was broken last night and still is).

I saw LOADS of AAA messages in the log:
https://gist.github.com/0e5c98856f0ede55e134

A simple POC using basic Auth works.

Feature loaded is: odl-restconf

Effectively this is blocking me. Anyone have any clues as to what is going on?



_______________________________________________
controller-dev mailing list
controller-dev at lists.opendaylight.org
https://lists.opendaylight.org/mailman/listinfo/controller-dev

https://gist.github.com/0e5c98856f0ede55e134




Anyone with any clues on why this just started?

Cheers

It's a typo in a yang's keyword in that model, not caught by yangtools at
compile time. Fix with the typo corrected has been merged today.

On Mon, Mar 23, 2015 at 3:55 PM, Tony Tkacik -X (ttkacik - Pantheon
Technologies SRO at Cisco) <ttkacik at cisco.com> wrote:

Hi Folks,

given that the MD-SAL is a simple data store, in the implementation of the
MD-SAL based Token Cache, we're looking at making some tradeoff's with the
challenge being the removal of expired tokens in a relatively timely manner.
Two approaches described below accomplish that but feature a tradeoff in
performance  ie We would like to collect feedback on these (or suggestions
for a alternative approaches):

1. On each cache API access (eg a new token add or validation), run a sweep
of all tokens in the store, cleansing out any expired ones.
Pro: Cache, when used, is thoroughly cleansed. Simple data structure
Con: Performance at scale, ie with 100k tokens we'd be reading running
blindly through the whole list each time.

2. Run a per user token sweep on API access, cleansing out any expired one.
Pro: Sweeper runs bound by the number of tokens in the accessing user's
store vs total token number in the system, ie More reasonable performance
at scale (Assuming a reasonable token/user distribution)
Con: Requires an additional data structure. Stale tokens for users who
don't access will continue to be visible until they access again.

In both approaches, stale tokens could appear in any restconf call on the
data-store, but throughout only valid tokens would be honored, ie
attempting to access with a stale token will be rejected, even if the
data-store still has that stale token.
We could redress this "display" issue only by having a scheduled cache
sweeper run, vs API access triggered runs. This could be option 3, however
we think it doesn't really buy much (there is still a good chance of a
restconf access in between cleaner runs), and for the rest having the
characteristics of 1 above.

Feedback's welcome.

Regards,
Wojciech.

already planned for Lithium.

Hi Folks,
as per our earlier discussion, during the TSC call the opinion was that the MD-SAL cluster capable AAA store would be of higher value to the community than Keystone integration, even as an experimental feature. Thus we'll be re-scoping the deliverables, and putting Keystone integration into the backlog.
We also had a chance to talk briefly regarding the chicken&egg AAA-Netconf issue, and we'll be getting guidance on a solution which appears to be already planned for Lithium.
Regards,
Wojciech.

Hi,

Today I won?t be able to make it at this time. Only slot I could make it is 9am PST?

That said, the proposal pretty much describes it all, i.e. Keeping the existing (implicit) API, slide in H2 instead of SqLite. Some considerations that come to apply are:

  *   Patch https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/15484/
  *   Encryption (should we use the inbuilt one, or have the writer /reader code do encryption?)

Yes, it was said to be a high prio activity, so we can see it as fair game. I?d think that it shouldn?t take more than a few days to do and test.

Regards,
-Wojciech.

Hi,

Today I won't be able to make it at this time. Only slot I could make it is 9am PST...

That said, the proposal pretty much describes it all, i.e. Keeping the existing (implicit) API, slide in H2 instead of SqLite. Some considerations that come to apply are:

  *   Patch https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/15484/
  *   Encryption (should we use the inbuilt one, or have the writer /reader code do encryption?)
Yes, it was said to be a high prio activity, so we can see it as fair game. I'd think that it shouldn't take more than a few days to do and test.

Regards,
-Wojciech.

Here is the status of replacing sqlite with H2.

b.      Fixed multiple issues with H2 implementation

c.       Tested by making Rest API calls to Domain

2.       Need Assistance Getting Code checked in.

a.       Here are highlevel steps I did to checkout and push code

                                                              i.      git review -d <review-id>{15484}

                                                            ii.      git add <changed files>

     We plan on being at the hackfest.  Our main focus there will be to work on creating unit and integration tests for the IDMLight components.

Regards
Eduardo

I took an action item at the TSC meeting last week to start a discussion
here if any needed to happen.

Basically, a few TSC meetings ago when the AAA project was talking about
how to get out of their current bind, the topic of Keystone federation came
up. I think Ed then mentioned that he'd heard people on the OpenStack side
saying to be very careful about how you go about doing keystone federation
because there were pitfalls that would be very dangerous.

So, I think that leaves us with a few questions:
1.) Is this all moot for now since we're likely not going to deliver any
Keystone federation in the near future?
2.) Do we have design documents for AAA federation?
3.) If so, are there people we should be reviewing them with?

Cheers,
--Colin
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20150414/2d34fc98/attachment.html>

This is somewhat more of a meta comment...:

My understanding (and I'm willing to be educated otherwise) of Keystone
Federation is that it
supports things like keystone-to-keystone federation or keystone consuming
identity properties
issued by an external identity provider.  I don't remember seeing anything
about Keystone providing
the identity properties and my experience with repeated querying Keystone
for identity information is
that it doesn't perform well.

Ryan

Hi,

Keystone federation indeed is a moot point at this stage. That said, the federation design is actually covered by our original AAA blueprint (via the Pluggable Authenticators): https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B2IWJPwtf67LeDd5a0JrZkpNaHc/edit?usp=sharing
 We currently already support limited federation by means of SSSD, or rather whatever* SSSD supports and is plugged into should work (*whatever not having been tested though).

Regards,
Wojciech.

Hi Folks,

with the MD-SAL (Cluster capable) token store nearly there,
https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/18418/ , I'd like to get some
feedback on how to proceed in terms of enabling it in the project vs the
current default (non cluster capable) token store.

In the patch above the MD-SAL token store is bundled under a newly defined
feature called odl-aaa-authn-cluster. With this approach in effect all the
aaa features should/would have the *-cluster  feature name.
This is something that most users of the system won't have a clue about
which has me concerned especially since various components, eg restconf,
netconf include odl-aaa-authn, which loads up the current non-cluster
capable default version(s) of aaa features.

Some choices are:
1. Change the default to be cluster capable, i.e. Keep the existing AAA
feature naming, but replace the non-cluster-capable bundles therein with
new ones as they come to be (eg the md-sal token cache), effectively
becoming the new default. This isolates the feature changes to AAA, and is
IMO the cleanest. The legacy bundles would get a no-cluster (or the like
name).
2. Change all dependent features to use a new aaa *-cluster feature set.

Welcome your feedback.

Thanks,
-Wojciech

From: ttkacik at cisco.com (Tony Tkacik -X (ttkacik - Pantheon Technologies SRO at Cisco))
Text:
Actually https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/19105/ this fixed it.

It was bug in Notification broker where using reflection we detected
all types of notifcations listener is listening for and original
algorhitm did not work for transtivelly implemented interfaces.

Tony

Hi All,

I have spent a few days trying to set up federated AAA using SSSO and
FreeIPA, but have hit some road blocks using
https://jdennis.fedorapeople.org/doc/sssd_configuration.pdf.  I was
wondering if anyone has successfully set up federated AAA with the Lithium
codebase?  If so, I would like to ask a few questions:

1) Which features did you install and in which order?
2) Were you able to successfully login to AAA DLUX using federated
credentials?  If so, which URL did you use to connect?  I have strange
behavior where I am able to access DLUX through ports 8181 and 8383 (8383
is the port I specified in etc/org.opendaylight.aaa.federation.cfg as
secureProxyPorts).
3) In /etc/httpd/conf.d/my_app.conf I specify "ProxyPass /
http://localhost:8383/", which causes 401 errors when I try to connect to
FreeIPA web console.  If I change to "ProxyPass /*aaa*
http://localhost:8383/", then it appears the two work side by side.  Do you
have any suggestions as to which location I should specify?

Ideally, I would like to get this solved quickly to ensure there are no
code gaps that need to be fulfilled before M5 and code freeze.  Please let
me know if you have successfully setup federated AAA.  I greatly appreciate
any help :).

Thanks,

Ryan Goulding

From: release-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:release-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Lorand Jakab -X (lojakab - AAP3 INC at Cisco)
Sent: Wednesday, May 13, 2015 11:27 AM
To: aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org
Cc: Release; lispflowmapping-dev at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [release] [lispflowmapping-dev] Beryllium build failure in LISP due to missing features-aaa artifact (Neutron dependency)

On 5/13/15 11:44 AM, Lori Jakab wrote:

Hi,

The lispflowmapping project recently bumped versions on master, and the
version bump patch had no issues.  However, we now have an issue in
SingleFeatureTest: when a feature with transitive dependency on
features-aaa is loaded an exception is thrown:

Error resolving
artifactorg.opendaylight.aaa:features-aaa:xml:features:0.3.0-SNAPSHOT:Could
not find artifact
org.opendaylight.aaa:features-aaa:xml:features:0.3.0-SNAPSHOT in
defaultlocal (file:/tmp/r/)

I checked that AAA did correctly bump versions, and the merge succeeded.
 I tried a "recheck" several times.  One thing that seemed a bit off was
the artifact type, the exceptions shows that the test is looking for an
XML type artifact and I see that the AAA feature artifacts are declared
as JAR, but that's not something changed recently, so I assume it should
still work.

Anyone has any insight?

This is the Gerrit with the issue:
https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/19976/

Thanks,
-Lori
On 5/13/15 11:44 AM, Lori Jakab wrote:

On 5/13/15 2:33 PM, Tony Tkacik -X (ttkacik - Pantheon Technologies SRO
at Cisco) wrote:

than "admin/admin" in DLUX. How can perform authentication.

mvn:org.opendaylight.aaa/features-aaa/0.1.0-SNAPSHOT/xml/features
Adding feature url

Hi All,

Due to some last minute appointments I won?t be able to attend the call today. Bridge should be still up in case anyone wants to chat and/or folks can catch me on IRC or mail.
That said, I?d like to list out a few things that require team attention:


  1.  SSSD Configuration w/IdP

We need to revisit the setup and working of this mechanism. So far, a few folks, myself included, haven?t been quite able to get it working using the existing documentation.
I filed https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=3322

2. SQL Injection
I see that the patch is there. However, could we have the robot tests run against it. In addition I have one comment that I?ll post.

3. Project Backlog for Berylium
Let?s please start putting proposals in. Currently we have (top level):

  *   AAA MD-SAL data store
  *   Completion of Authz
  *   General Keystore (SNMP, Netconf)
  *   Keystone (although validity of this approach has been put in doubt)

Regards,
Wojciech.

On Wed, Jun 3, 2015 at 3:13 PM, Lnt OpenDayLight <opendaylight.lnt at gmail.com

Hi Ryan,

it took a while but I found the issue. It seems that someone removed the
connector for IdmLight in the controller project, but given that it doesn't
actually need to live on a separate port I moved it to the 8181 one.
Proposed fix is in:

https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/21891

curl -X GET -v -H "Content-type:application/json"
http://127.0.0.1:8181/auth/v1/users

Will get you started.

I have another fix for the authentication of the API end point, but the
above will get you started.

Cheers,
Wojciech.

Hi,

the basic token-based access works as follows:
- Request a token using credentials from the API at /oauth2/token
- Embed the token in an Oauth2 header when accessing any API

Now, the above isn't really suitable for GUI access, unless you have a
federated form of it, which is what the SSSD module adds. In other words:
- Use browser to authenticate with a federated IdP (eg facebook).
- Use the provided "token" to access ODL

Regards,
Wojciech.

WRT DLUX, I am cc'ing the dlux-dev mailing list, as they have a way to
cache credentials for use with that application (I am not an expert but I
believe it may utilize CORS).  In terms of generic AAA (not necessarily
applied to DLUX), the driving use case is protecting REST endpoints.  By
default, the REST endpoints utilize HTTP, and HTTP is stateless so their is
no way of tracking who is "logged in".

An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20150629/f6763b69/attachment.html>

Currently, DLUX does use AAA, but only basic authentication. The default credentials that AAA provides is admin/admin for basic Auth. DLUX use them to authenticate and keep them in user session for subsequent requests.

I think there was a component added in AAA to keep all the authenticated tokens in md-sal datastore. That way it can be tracked, which user is logged and till what time that token is valid. We might want to use something similar in DLUX for authentication.

DLUX will also need to utilize user management of AAA to fully utilize this.

Thanks,
- Harman

Subject: Re: [dlux-dev] [Aaa-dev] AAA integration with DLUX Lithium

WRT DLUX, I am cc'ing the dlux-dev mailing list, as they have a way to cache credentials for use with that application (I am not an expert but I believe it may utilize CORS).  In terms of generic AAA (not necessarily applied to DLUX), the driving use case is protecting REST endpoints.  By default, the REST endpoints utilize HTTP, and HTTP is stateless so their is no way of tracking who is "logged in".

On Tue, Jun 30, 2015 at 2:50 PM, Colin Dixon <colin at colindixon.com> wrote:

Colin,

It appears the code may be broken for this case, so thank you for opening
the bug.  You are supposed to be able to change this sort of thing using
this process:


Issue a PUT request to the correct user id with the new payload.  For
example, to change user admin with starting password admin to
password=newpassword:
*curl -X PUT -u admin:admin -H "Content-type: application/json"
--data-binary @user.json http://localhost:8181/auth/v1/users/1
<http://localhost:8181/auth/v1/users/1>*
{"userid":1,"name":"admin","description":"admin
user","enabled":true,"email":"","password":"dog"}
*user.json contents: (i.e., cat user.json)*
{"userid":1,"name":"admin","description":"admin
user","enabled":true,"email":"","password":"newpassword"}

However, it appears that when you stop then restart the controller you end
up with multiple admin users.  This means that the current system is not
enforcing unique usernames w/ PUT request (not sure if this is part of the
original spec).  So you will end up with a new user, instead of a modified
one.  There is no POST capability for users that I know of in the current
code, so it looks like the only way to do this is via psql right now.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On 26 June 2015 at 15:47, Wojciech Dec (wdec) <wdec at cisco.com<mailto:wdec at cisco.com>> wrote:
Hi Thanh,

I started merging some commits that restructure the project. All seems to
have been going fine, until I started getting the below after merge. The
logs show an error:

[ERROR] No Repository settings defined in the job configuration or
distributionManagement of the module.


Which doesn?t mean I understand why it actually gets thrown

Could you take a look?

Hi Wojciech,

Looks like in your project restructuring you may have removed the necessary <distributionManagement> sections from your parent pom somewhere. This section is needed by Maven in order to know where to push your artifacts. I noticed a few other projects have some patches in Gerrit to remove this section as well... so I'm not sure how the decision was made to start removing these sections but changes to Jenkins infra would be required for this to work.

I opened up a new thread on the mailing list thread here [1] to find out if this is a direction projects really want to go as I'm worried these Gerrit patches that are removing these sections will catch projects by surprise when their merge jobs start failing.

Regards,

Thanh

[1] https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/release/2015-June/003057.html

I opened up a new thread on the mailing list thread here [1] to find out if this is a direction projects really want to go as I'm worried these Gerrit patches that are removing these sections will catch projects by surprise when their merge jobs start failing.

Regards,

Thanh

[1] https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/release/2015-June/003057.html

Hi all,

At your convenience, please review these patches:
stable/lithium: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/23654/
master: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/23653/

It appears that when AAA switched to H2 at some point, the file name
convention changed to "idmlight.db.mv.db" from "idmlight.db".  Our
StoreBuilder.init() method is triggered on the non-existence of
"idmlight.db", so it gets called every time the controller is started
resulting in multiple "admin" and "user" accounts.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

issue though).
There's something specific in the the setup you're using, or perhaps its
startup. As noted the Token Service is never activated, and its actually
one of the handful of AAA services that are driven by the config
sub-system, so at least for this case the load ordering seems not to be the
issue. Would it be an option to get a VM image?
Given that we don't have a good understanding of the root cause of the
issue you're seeing, giving an ETA is rather difficult at this stage.

Wojciech.

Hi



I am currently using Lithium distribution and installed the feature "odl-aaa-authn"



installing the above feature turned the karaf into a web container and when I ran "web:list" , I see following web-contexts are available



opendaylight-user at root>web:list<mailto:opendaylight-user at root>web:list>
ID  | State       | Web-State   | Level | Web-ContextPath    | Name
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
248 | Active      | Deployed    | 80    | /oauth2            | aaa-authn-sts (0.2.0.Lithium)
252 | Active      | Deployed    | 80    | /auth              | aaa-idmlight (0.2.0.Lithium)

278 | Active      | Deployed    | 80    | /apidoc            | MD SAL Rest Api Doc Generator (1.2.0.Lithium)

Hi,

the magic, as I understand it, happens by means of the "war" feature that
comes as part of karaf:
https://karaf.apache.org/manual/latest/users-guide/webcontainer.html

The packaging up of the servlet into an OSGi bundle is done by the
maven-bundle-plugin extension
https://ops4j1.jira.com/wiki/display/paxweb/OSGi-fy+your+WAR

Hope that helps.

-Wojciech.

Subject: Re: [OpenDaylight TSC] Fwd: [Aaa-dev] ODL AAA project membership change

Hi All,
having spoken to the new team of AAA developers and having reviewed the deliverables status, we have identified some possible ways forward.
First off, a status update of the "planned" deliverables, as I currently see them. The color coding is indicative of resourcing and state:
1. MD-SAL based Token cache
Green. On track. No new external APIs introduced. No inter project dependencies.
2. Keystone Federation
Yellow. Code said to be 50% complete,  Feature s & POMs checked in. No inter project dependencies so far.

3. AAA Clustering and Persistence
Red. Dependency on Persistence project w/ new API to which the AAA store code would be refactored to. No resource in the team identified to take this forward.
The current thinking of the AAA team from the last call is that this deliverable should be re-scoped to an MD-SAL based credential store*
4. CI Testing
Green'ish. Test only. No new API. Draft test plan available. Robot test script resource still in place (but hasn't been heard of in a while)
5. Key Manager
Yellow. A new API needed, and a basic model for it has been supplied but it appears incomplete. This deliverable should also address Netconf/other-key-storage requirements, but these were not scoped so far (eg Netconf team didn't have cycles to look into this). I am waiting to hear from the resource(s) who were driving it, however they also appear to be affected.
Now my assessments are:
- The team sees item 3. above as the one that would provide most value to the community, and thus of highest priority. However in it's scoped form, ie using a new external galera DB + the dependency on the persitence project ,which also appears to have been affected by resource changes, the team considers that an MD-SAL based store approach would be more appropriate, also for the long term. The AAA team is visibly interested in pursing this approach, however it would in effect be a re-scoping of the item at a rather late stage. Nevertheless this, would be a better course of action that no AAA clustering support at all for Lithium.
- Keystone federation can proceed but new team taking over so it is at some ramp-up-time risk. I'll do my best to mitigate this by providing support, but ultimately it comes down to new folks who are taking over.
- The key manager in a simple MD-SAL store form as currently proposed could still be progressed, but we appear to don't have the resource for it (or at least it wasn't identified last week).
Given the above, I would like to ask for some feedback, and if necessary time on a call. The question & options as I see them are:
1. Should item 3 be re-scoped to an MD-SAL backed store at this stage, and still be aimed for Lithium?
2. Item 5 could continue if a resource shows up this week. Otherwise I'd take it off the table and put it back into the backlog.
3. Given that we're not only tight on the time-lines but also facing a skills-ramp-up time, assuming resources do come forward, should either/both of the above be taken down a notch and put on track as experimental features?
Regards,
Wojciech.

Hi all,
After getting some of your inputs i have come up with the following 
model for AAA. The main guidelines were:

  * Fix historical modelling issue using incremented integer as an
    identifier for model elements to ease the interaction of other north
    bound and other applications with AAA.
  * Aligned to multiple tenancy.
  * Aligned to clustering environment.
  * Aligned to MDSAL as a data store (if will be chosen in the future).

Please share your thoughts and inputs, i will be happy to answer any 
questions regarding.


Thanks,
           Sharon.

From: Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
Date: Mon, Aug 10, 2015 at 12:37 PM
Subject: Re: [Aaa-dev] AAA Data Model
To: Sharon Aicler <saichler at cisco.com>


Hi Sharon,

I disagree with eliminating domain id and including "domain (string)" in
the user table.  This implicitly forces a 1:1 relationship between user and
domain (a user can currently have grants on multiple domains, and we should
continue to allow this for admin and super users).  Furthermore, the
combination of user at domain in the proposed Users table goes against 1st
Normal Form of db design;  each column should contain exactly one piece of
information.  ryan at coke and ryan at sprite can certainly refer to the same
user "ryan", and "ryan" should be treated as the same user (not two entries
in the user table).

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Mon, Aug 10, 2015 at 12:21 PM, Sharon Aicler <saichler at cisco.com> wrote:

Hi Ryan,
To your points:

  *   I have considered both options, however keeping other entities seperated and undepended from the Domain will be causing issues with clustering and potential duplicate records per user (event not in a clustering environment). The advantages of keeping it as is are minor (I cannot even think of any), hence I have coupled the entities to the Domain.
  *   My first version was using a compound key (e.g. user+domain), however Wojciech pointed out that MDSAL does not have compound keys, hence I reverted back to the "entity at domain". Please see bullet #3 on slide 4...

Thanks,
           Sharon.

* WRT to clustering; we need to find a safe way handle non-duplicate data
through transaction locking; in relational database design we can achieve
this through transactions/rollbacks.  If there is no way to do this
utilizing MD-SAL, perhaps it is not an ideal candidate.
* WRT to a compound key, this implies that ryan at coke and ryan at sdn are two
separate users; each with different passwords/salts/emails etc.  This is
dangerous, and necessitats data redundancy in the database.  If MD-SAL
cannot handle a compound key, then perhaps this is evidence that we should
rely on a different backing data store.


Regards,

Ryan Goulding
