On Mon, Aug 10, 2015 at 12:58 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Hi Ryan,
The motivation is to exit the AAA from what I consider as far more 
dangerous implementation it is in...

I do see and understand your point, however considering the "danger" on 
both path, my intention is to have "ryan at coke" & "ryan at sdn" as two 
separate users. To my best knowledge keeping it "as is" is far more 
dangerous... If you don't have your relations enforced by the data store 
schema, we are going to face far more complex issues, challenges and 
performance elements.

How will you know which user belong to which domain? if ryan at coke is not 
the same user as ryan at sdn, how will you distinguish between them? 
Keeping the userID as a unique number?

If you keep the user ID, you cannot distinguish if multiple nodes are 
creating the same user or a different one for "ryan", hence you will 
forced to develop a highly complex locking mechanism which will be 
tightly coupled to the persistence implementation as to develop it you 
need to know its clustering method.

The locking mechanism you will develop it eventually a clustering 
mechanism and using MDSAL is the way to avoid re-developing a clustering 
mechanism. If we choose a different data store than MDSAL, the locking 
mechanism will act differently, for example if we choose Cassandra, 
which allows inserting from multiple nodes (not like MDSAL data broker 
that only the master is distributing the data), your locking mechanism 
will be different.

Performance, No way for an application to determinate which is the 
correct user without first querying the Domains to get the domain 
id->query the users to get a collection of "ryan" users -> query the 
grants to get the correct grant.

Those are just some points that pop into my mind...

On 08/10/2015 09:59 AM, Ryan Goulding wrote:

Yeah, good catch, does anybody verified REST authentication is still available in master?

BR/Luis

Just adding some points for clarification:

- MD-SAL is currently the only cluster-capable store that works in ODL "out
of the box" (ie doesn't require some add-on installed). This is one key
motivation for the "MD-SAL data store".
- Yang does offer lists with "compound keys", however they're not very
commonly used. I believe that the reason is actually that they are
considered as strictly primary keys, while folks would like a "map of maps"
type of construct, while allowing for direct keyed leaf access. Anyway, we
can attempt to use it and see.

Now, re the data model proposal, I think that the current model's primary
key is a problem not only in terms of concurrency; it lends itself for an
odd API, where a user has to know the system assigned user-id to ask for
the user-data.
Going with the user at domain, and dropping the domain column, or a compound
key would appear to be preferable.

-Wojciech.

On Mon, Aug 10, 2015 at 5:12 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

When you try to enforce a relation between two persisted entities via 
"running code" and not via the schema, you have to consider race 
condition between two machines trying to create the same entities and 
the same relation between them @ the same time. Assuming they can work 
in parallel, you have to develop a locking mechanism... To develop a 
locking mechanism you need to deeply understand your persistence layer 
and how does it do clustering as you do not want to re-write what is 
already supported by the persistence layer, but on the other hand you 
want to cover scenarios that the persistence layer clustering does not 
support. For example:

If the MDSAL is the persistence layer, we don't need to write a very 
sophisticated locking mechanism as the MDSAL cluster data broker is 
implementing RAFT, hence only the master writes to the Data Broker and 
propagate the transaction to the slaves so it might be simple.

But If we use Cassandra for example, it implements gossip protocol which 
allows different nodes in the cluster to write in parallel to the same 
"table". In this case we need a locking mechanism as if entity creation 
will happen on two machines in parallel we will end up with two records 
in our table if the entity ID is uniquely generated per entity creation.

Today there isn't any locking mechanism so in a clustering environment 
it will not work. Developing a locking mechanism require you to couple 
it to persistence implemented protocol, which violates the plug-able 
persistence capabilities.

To solve this race condition we "encode" the entity relation in the 
model so @ worst case we will have double writing to the same record 
instead of two records.

On 08/10/2015 11:53 AM, Luis Gomez wrote:

In my proposal a domain cannot be null... A User must exist "under" a 
domain and so is a Role. A Grant is the vessel in which you assign roles 
for a user inside a domain. A User can have multiple Roles in a domain 
because different applications might assign different capabilities to 
different roles and some users might need to consume several roles 
capabilities in the same application.

Thanks,
           Sharon.

On 31 August 2015 at 20:37, Thanh Ha <thanh.ha at linuxfoundation.org<mailto:thanh.ha at linuxfoundation.org>> wrote:
So with Ed's help we now have a new conclusion. If you look at the output of "mvn dependency:tree" you can see that there's a cyclic dependency being caused by a dependency features-netconf.

[INFO] +- org.opendaylight.netconf:features-netconf:xml:features:1.0.0-SNAPSHOT:runtime
[INFO] |  +- org.opendaylight.aaa:features-aaa:xml:features:0.3.0-SNAPSHOT:runtime

So we think that the root cause is that when building features-aaa we depend on features-netconf which in turn depends on the previous version of features-aaa which is pulling in the out of date features.xml and causing the build issue we are seeing.

We think that the cyclic dependency will need to be broken but I'm not sure where this should happen.

Is there someone on the netconf project able to look into what our options are here?
features-aaa seems to depend on netconf-api. AAA only needs org.opendaylight.controller.netconf.auth.AuthProvider, while NETCONF needs odl-aaa-netconf-plugin.

There is an explicit FIXME in netconf/features/netconf/src/main/resources/features.xml to this effect. This is a rehash of that old controller/aaa cycle, this time with 'odl-netconf-ssh', not 'odl-restconf'.

I don't remember the intended project graph, but I think both AAA and NETCONF should depend on controller. If that is the case, AuthProvider needs to be moved into AAA and we'll have only NETCONF depending on AAA -- cycle solved.

Alternatively we can move odl-aaa-netconf-plugin into NETCONF, as that may make more sense.


Thanks Robert,

So this is currently a blocker and we're unable to build Beryllium at all at this point. But sounds like we have some possible solutions, is there someone on the aaa or netconf projects who can take ownership of bug 4216 [1] and get this resolved?

I'm happy to help where I can.

Thanks,

Thanh

[1] https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=4216

From: vrpolak at cisco.com (Vratko Polak -X (vrpolak - PANTHEON TECHNOLOGIES at Cisco))
Text:
Hi Netconf and Integration/distribution devs.

Bumping this thread now, let me know if I got
any new e-mail list address or topic wrong.

So, Beryllium Restconf functionality is now provided by
Netconf project, and odl-aaa-authn is still
commented out of odl-restconf feature definition.

So far, I have found no trace of Lithium Controller
document promising Restconf with AAA,
so probably no official "API contract" was broken.
Also, I agree that Netconf does not need to depend on AAA.

However, odl-restconf was a well-known cross-project feature,
ODL users may just assume it works the same in Beryllium.

My current idea of how to satisfy everyone goes like this:
Remove odl-restconf from Netconf features
(citing odl-restconf-noauth as the new top-level feature),
but at the same time define odl-restconf
in Integration/distribution features (index/ ones).
That way, Netconf will still not depend on AAA,
but the cross-project feature will be available.

Similar approach may be used for *-rest and *-ui features.
Defining them in integration/distribution
will remove dependency cycles (e.g. Dlux and Openflowplugin).

Vratko.

Subject: Re: [integration-dev] [controller-dev] Beryllium odl-restconf without auth?

Hi Phil,

Thanks for your prompt reply.  I apologize for not getting back sooner;  I
have been doing quite a bit of research into this one.  Simply put, there
aren't any non *GPL licensed Java Radius clients.  That said, both Tiny
Radius and JRadius (the "top" *GPL licensed radius clients) haven't been
updated in nearly half a decade so I don't know how good those are either.

For now, Radius is not a top priority for Beryllium release.  I am working
on creating my own basic Radius client plugin based on Apache sources that
can support frame building for basic AuthN and AuthZ.  I think this will be
a better approach for AAA project needs.  Please feel free to disregard
this request, and thanks very much for taking a look into this for me!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Hi An,

1) We are finishing up resolving inter-project dependencies.  There are two
patches for AAA and netconf (restconf) which are currently in review for
the Jersey 2.X / JAXRS 2.X upgrade:
NETCONF: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/27397/
AAA:           https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/27584/
There are other projects that may be affected by these changes, so we are
going to issue a weather advisory later today concerning the change (as
well as prepare some more patch sets for affected projects).  This is a
much larger change that affects several more projects than we originally
anticipated.

2)
*Shiro: *No,  the odl-aaa-shiro feature has not been added to the
integration project.  This is due to the fact that it will likely never be
advertised, as it is more of a replacement for odl-aaa-authn.  When the
time comes to make the switch, we will point the odl-aaa-authn feature to
install the odl-aaa-shiro feature (which is really internal only).
*MD-SAL: * No, this work is still in review here
https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/26420/.  We *NEED* to merge this
patch prior to adding the feature in integration.

3) We have not submitted a plan yet,  I can work on this today & tomorrow
and provide an update to you.  Our main system tests were merged to the
integration project in this patch
https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/23385/.

Please let me know if you need anything else, and I will gladly help out.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Hi George,

I am assuming you are using stable/lithium based on the stack trace you
provided, is this correct?  My initial guess is this;  you are providing
"admin:admin" in plain text while it should be provided in Base64.  Current
versions of Postman should automatically convert this;  which version are
you using?  I just tested this with stable/lithium and ensured it worked
properly for me.

Thanks,
Ryan

George, did you get a chance to try this using base 64 encoded
credentials?  As Tony said, if you use the "Authorization" tab in POSTMAN
the formatting should be automatically converted to base 64 for you.  If
this auto-conversion doesn't work for you, then try using the string that
Tony provided:
Authorization: Basic YWRtaW46YWRtaW4=

I filed this bug against the unclear error message [1] and this patch to
clean up that code [2].  Hopefully this will make it easier for future
restconf users :).

Maxime et al.,

This distribution is quite old, and there was a JDBC driver change between Helium-SR4 and Lithium;  the new driver is a pure java implementation and thus is a bit more portable.  My initial gut reaction is to recommend loading a newer version.  I do not have a PC using that architecture, but I'll try to help.  Helium-SR4 came out shortly after I started on the AAA project;  but here is a bit of debug information for what its worth.  First of all, try to check if the database file is created.  From your karaf home directory, execute the following:

Hi An,

1) We are finishing up resolving inter-project dependencies.  There are two patches for AAA and netconf (restconf) which are currently in review for the Jersey 2.X / JAXRS 2.X upgrade:
NETCONF: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/27397/
AAA:           https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/27584/
There are other projects that may be affected by these changes, so we are going to issue a weather advisory later today concerning the change (as well as prepare some more patch sets for affected projects).  This is a much larger change that affects several more projects than we originally anticipated.

2)
Shiro: No,  the odl-aaa-shiro feature has not been added to the integration project.  This is due to the fact that it will likely never be advertised, as it is more of a replacement for odl-aaa-authn.  When the time comes to make the switch, we will point the odl-aaa-authn feature to install the odl-aaa-shiro feature (which is really internal only).
MD-SAL:  No, this work is still in review here https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/26420/.  We NEED to merge this patch prior to adding the feature in integration.

3) We have not submitted a plan yet,  I can work on this today & tomorrow and provide an update to you.  Our main system tests were merged to the integration project in this patch https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/23385/.

Please let me know if you need anything else, and I will gladly help out.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

ODL SFC uses jersey-client to communicate with southbound devices that

Hi Alioune,

I have added in the aaa-dev list, as we try to keep discussions public so
other members of the community can chime in.  The current architecture is
able to support several forms of IdP through proxying through Apache;
 basically we rely upon mod_auth_lookup apache extensions and essentially
re-use the federated IdP code.  However, only SSSD is "supported", and I
have had some issues setting up some parts of that.  The idea is we gather
roles stored in the IdP to determine roles in the AAA system through
mapping rules.

Per the AAA team discussion at the 2015 ODL Summit, we are now pursuing
federated IdP using Apache Shiro.  Apache Shiro comes with built in support
for LDAP, SQL, Basic and a few other providers.  The other ones we can
create through extension of the Shiro AuthorizingRelam class.  A good
portion of this code is in the code base, but currently blocked by a few
major version upgrades I am pursuing across projects.

What type of system (i.e., protocol) are you interested in trying to use
for federation?  As I mentioned earlier, integration is meant to tie the
whole project together, and is probably not useful for this new use case
you have brought up.  You will probably want to clone the aaa.git
repository which contains the existing federated code.

Hope this helps,

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

You are still being sufficiently vague that I don't know your intention.
Is the third party IdP application something you are creating as part of
your company?  Although ODL certainly appreciates contributions from
everyone, we have to be careful that all code merged is vendor-neutral and
promotes the good of the project, not a specific company.  Since AAA is an
offset 0 project, there are also some pretty strict rules concerning what
code we can change during certain phases of the development cycle.  Thus,
it is good to discuss your intentions openly so it is clear what is allowed
and not allowed.

I encourage you to join our weekly meeting today at 9AM PST [1] and join
our mailing list [2].  Generally the meeting is the best place to get
started since we can give you ideas about certain needed changes, since the
regulars are pretty familiar with the pitfalls of the current solution.  We
also have a few big changes that are up in the air that will be merged
soon, which would be a good place for you to start looking as well.  Our
wiki [3] has some high level drawings of the Lithium based architecture,
though some of that has changed in Beryllium and we have not had a chance
to update it.

WRT the code, you need to download the aaa.git repository to see the code.
git clone ssh://{your_username}@git.opendaylight.org:29418/aaa.git

Hope this helps.



Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Hi Yuling,

I have reverted these changes due to some unforeseen issues with downstream
projects.  Initially, my testing led me to believe that consuming projects
of odl-restconf would not need to upgrade their jersey version;  however it
appears that having multiple versions of jersey framework causes quite a
few issues with some of the projects consuming odl-restconf.  I will being
work to see which downstream projects need changes;  this is likely going
to require many more patches across projects than initially anticipated.  I
will alert teams when the patches are prepared.  I apologize for any
breakages that occurred as a result of this.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

java classes in folder [2]  and then modify them for redirecting users'
credentials
(login&password) to a remote server that will tell aaa wheter or not to
allow a user accessing on ODL resoures.  The exchange between aaa and the
remote server will be done using simple REST API; the idea is to allow
external users/processes having 'admin' or 'user' access right in ODL
without being registered in h2 database before their authentication.

module's behavior thanks to the previous step.

use the aaa I have modified ?

On 29 October 2015 at 12:36, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com> wrote:
On 11/02/2015 08:11 AM, Alioune wrote:

Hi Dear John,

I am working on moon project [1], a policy-based user-centric security
management system for cloud infrastructure that aims to allow users setting
fine granularity of authorization in cloud platform and SDN controllers.
user-centric: Moon enables administrators or a third-party application to
define, configure and manage its policies
policy-based: the policy-based approach bypasses the heterogeneity of
different cloud resources pool, the management is achieved through a
standard policy instead of a standard interface. Each module of a cloud
infrastructure only needs to accept the policy defined by moon.
authorization enforcement (in OpenStack): the security policy in Moon is
enforced by authorization mechanism in Keystone and Nova. All the
operations in Keystone and Nova are controlled and validated by Moon.
(OpenStack is not
the only scope of moon)

Actually the project does not focussed on the usage of ODL as
MechanismDriver for Neutron ML2 pluin and as you said before in such a case
authentication between AAA and Keystone is succesully achieved using
configuration [2] but I just want to control the aaa authorization from
moom by redirecting authentication requests to moon via API calls.

Hope it is more clear ?

Best Regards

[1] https://wiki.opnfv.org/moon

[2] [[post-config|/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini]]
[ml2_odl]
url=http://odl_server:8080/controller/nb/v2/neutron
username=admin
password=admin

Hi Keith,

Are you using the auth or cluster auth feature?


Please try the following patch that is being reviewed, it might help in this case.

https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/29608/


When in karaf and the bundle does not come up, please execute the following command to see if the karaf identifies any issue:

bundle:diag


If there isn't any output of the above command, it might be that the bundles are still loading.


If nothing happens after a min or so, try to invoke the command:

do the following:

"?feature:list -i | grep aaa"

and then

"feature:install <the aaa feature that is installed>"


When you get the output error, just send it to me.

If you don't get an error, you might need to wait for the bundles to come up.



Thanks,

           Sharon.

appears that these issues are caused by some race conditions in dependency
injection, and only happen for some people on some systems.  I have never
actually seen this on my machine, and I compile aaa/netconf multiple times
a day.  My apologies for any breakages; please compile the aaa.git master
locally to fix these issues.

These changes started to be seen after we merged the md-sal data store.  I am temporarily reverting these changes to alleviate these failures.  It appears that these issues are caused by some race conditions in dependency injection, and only happen for some people on some systems.  I have never actually seen this on my machine, and I compile aaa/netconf multiple times a day.  My apologies for any breakages; please compile the aaa.git master locally to fix these issues.

Revert changes are [1] [2] [3].

Best Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Hi,
With limited browsing of the logs on my mobile it seems that the real issue here is the data broker not getting started and not electing a leader after long...long time, hence AAA just exposed an issue that was "undercover" as we started to use the MDSAL data broker in clustering mode.

Reverting the AAA code will just "cover" the issue again as you will be able to login with the AAA using the local H2 database but your controller/cluster will be actually useless without any data broker (unless your app is not using the data broker).

Can you submit the log to the controller-dev mailing list? Please include some description of your setup, the number of openflow connected swithes and your clustering configuration so the specialist can help fine tune it.

Not sure it is relevant any more but it might be that you enable persistence on the "operational" data store and getting hit by the statistic manager or in this version the statistic manager is not cluster aware so with openflow clustering each node in the clustering is pushing the data so please highlight that info in this email with the logs.

Sent from my Android phone using Symantec TouchDown (www.symantec.com)

Hi All,

We are still investigating the root cause for this, and discovered it may
be due to loading latencies of the controller, or some other underlying
issues that have not yet been uncovered.  In order to alleviate some of the
pain associated with this issue, we have reverted our store from an md-sal
based store to the h2-based version, which seems to help.  Please report
back if you are still seeing issues.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

We took out md-sal as the *default* backing datastore, so h2 should be used
unless you specified otherwise (I doubt this is the case).  There were
about 5 patches, so there is a small chance that if you missed one then you
could be using the old md-sal store implementation.  When did you try to
compile?  If you pick up the latest artifacts this should be working.
Please let me know if you continue having troubles after using latest
artifacts, and I'll be more than happy to take a look!

Hi Naresh,

I asked because I wanted to ensure you were using the latest AAA
artifacts... the md-sal ones don't import the odl-restconf.  Maven will
cache artifacts for a waiting period if you do not force an update in your
local m2 repository.  I pulled the sfc code base this morning and ensured
that the h2 datastore is used for AAA (after installing
odl-sfc-provider-rest, you will see a file called idmlight.db.mv.db file in
your karaf root directory).  I then ensured I could make 1000 rest calls
with authentication, which also seemed to work.  I was also able to access
apidocs after install odl-sfc-ui feature.

Can you please provide:
1) the exact features you are installing
2) the rest call you are attempting to make, including all applicable
authentication headers
3) a karaf log
4) are you in a cluster?

Thanks.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Thu, Dec 3, 2015 at 1:01 AM, NareshA kumar <nka at criterionnetworks.com>
wrote:

Also, when you see "Please provide username:password in base64 format."  it
generally means that you are not properly encoding your authorization
header.  For reference, this is what the authorization header looks like
for admin/admin
Authorization: Basic YWRtaW46YWRtaW4=

Most REST clients including postman have functionality to add
authentication which do the encoding for you.  What rest call causes this
error/is it properly encoding the authorization credentials?

Is anyone else in the sfc team currently running into this issue?

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On 30 November 2015 at 14:55, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com<mailto:ryandgoulding at gmail.com>> wrote:
1: What's the difference between client and user in ODL ?

I am afraid I don't know what you are referring to here;  is there somewhere specific that you saw this nomenclature (wiki, install guide, etc.)?

 2: How to associate a mininet network to a specific domain in order to display topology and allow network management for only users that belong to the domain ?

Although domains exist as a field in AAA (mandatory per user), they are largely not used.  If a user has a "grant" (link between user and role), they can make any rest call (in the current code base).  This functionality slid off the radar over time since there has been a high turnover in AAA team since its inception.  For now, it is recommended to only use the default sdn domain;  we can add support for multi-tenancy as an item to our trello backlog.  Right now the mapping simply does not exist.

Hope this helps.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Fri, Dec 4, 2015 at 4:49 AM, NareshA kumar <nka at criterionnetworks.com>

Okay I dug a little deeper and was able to make this happen locally on my
system by lowering my VM resources and installing a feature that had more
involved (openflowplugin-flow-resources-ui), and I think I found one more
patch that needs to be made;  AAA assumes that the store is injected in 30
seconds or it gives up trying to initialize users.  The feature you install
likely has a lot of dependencies and takes a bit longer (OSGI is non
deterministic).  I am filing this bug [1] and this patch [2] to fix this.
Your log has this message, which leads me to believe this is the right fix:

*2015-12-04 13:43:58,150 | INFO  | pool-8-thread-1  | StoreBuilder
            | 243 - org.opendaylight.aaa.idmlight - 0.3.0.SNAPSHOT | Store
is not available, aborting initialization*

Apologies for this class loading issue;  these are pretty tough to debug.
Hope this helps, let me know if you continue running into this!

Best Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Best Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Also, when you see "Please provide username:password in base64 format."  it generally means that you are not properly encoding your authorization header.  For reference, this is what the authorization header looks like for admin/admin
Authorization: Basic YWRtaW46YWRtaW4=

Most REST clients including postman have functionality to add authentication which do the encoding for you.  What rest call causes this error/is it properly encoding the authorization credentials?

Is anyone else in the sfc team currently running into this issue?

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On 30 November 2015 at 14:55, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com<mailto:ryandgoulding at gmail.com>> wrote:
1: What's the difference between client and user in ODL ?

I am afraid I don't know what you are referring to here;  is there somewhere specific that you saw this nomenclature (wiki, install guide, etc.)?

 2: How to associate a mininet network to a specific domain in order to display topology and allow network management for only users that belong to the domain ?

Although domains exist as a field in AAA (mandatory per user), they are largely not used.  If a user has a "grant" (link between user and role), they can make any rest call (in the current code base).  This functionality slid off the radar over time since there has been a high turnover in AAA team since its inception.  For now, it is recommended to only use the default sdn domain;  we can add support for multi-tenancy as an item to our trello backlog.  Right now the mapping simply does not exist.

Hope this helps.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

[ryan at awesomeo opendaylight]$ curl -d 'grant_type=password&username=admin&password=admin&scope=sdn' http://localhost:8181/oauth2/token

[ryan at awesomeo opendaylight]$
[ryan at awesomeo opendaylight]$ curl -X POST -H 'Authorization: Bearer e7f8f6ad-ce52-340e-8da3-4d1d2b001732' -H 'Content-type:application/json' -d '{"domainid": "1","name":"R&D","enabled":"true"}' http://localhost:8181/auth/v1/domains
{"domainid":2,"name":"R&D","description":"","enabled":true}
[ryan at awesomeo opendaylight]$

Hope this helps.

Ryan Goulding

On 30 November 2015 at 14:55, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com<mailto:ryandgoulding at gmail.com>> wrote:
1: What's the difference between client and user in ODL ?

I am afraid I don't know what you are referring to here;  is there somewhere specific that you saw this nomenclature (wiki, install guide, etc.)?

 2: How to associate a mininet network to a specific domain in order to display topology and allow network management for only users that belong to the domain ?

Although domains exist as a field in AAA (mandatory per user), they are largely not used.  If a user has a "grant" (link between user and role), they can make any rest call (in the current code base).  This functionality slid off the radar over time since there has been a high turnover in AAA team since its inception.  For now, it is recommended to only use the default sdn domain;  we can add support for multi-tenancy as an item to our trello backlog.  Right now the mapping simply does not exist.

Hope this helps.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

These are likely due to a few things.  I haven't heard of this yet, thanks
for letting me know.  It is hard to debug since [1] masked the SQLException
stacktrace.  I see two main issues:
1) No synchronization barrier around table creation, causing the "table
already exists jdbc SQLException) [2]
2) SQLExceptions are masked by IDMStoreException (which makes it impossible
for me to tell why the "readDomain()" call failed. [3]

I have filed bugs for both of these and I am working on fixes right now.
Whether they are related is not possible to tell with this stack trace.
Hopefully after I fix Bug4782 we can tell if this happens again.  I
apologize for any inconveniences.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

[1]
https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/30315/3/aaa-h2-store/src/main/java/org/opendaylight/aaa/h2/persistence/H2Store.java

[3] https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=4783

Hi

We are from the Controller Shield Project group whose primary goal is to create a security related repository within ODL. In ODL Be, we could create a repository that holds OpenFlow PacketIn related security information. 

As part of our ODL Boron activities, we would like to extend our project to include ODL NB access related security information. In this regard, we are looking for successful and failed login attempts to ODL. 

It will be of great help to us if you could tell  whether  there is a way in the current AAA implementation to get this information of failed and successful login attempts.

If already implemented we would like to know how to enable the particular accouting service. If not implemented is there a workaround for getting this piece of info.

Hi Thomas,

Currently these are persisted to the karaf.log, which is unfortunately the
only interface currently.  Technically, you could scrape the information
out of there, but that is painful.  That said, in Boron we are more than
willing to help provide hooks for this information;  I will add this to the
release backlog.  I imagine we could create an event listener architecture,
and you could register as a listener for login attempts.

Best Regards,

Ryan Goulding

The controller-csit-3node-clustering-only-beryllium tests succeeded but
controller-csit-3node-clustering-all-beryllium. I assume they run the same
car/people tests - the difference is that "only" installs only the cluster
test app and "all" installs all (40 something?) apps. The "all" tests
failed due to "No RPC implementation" for people which likely means the
cluster test app hadn't started yet due to all the others apps to load. So
the test would need to retry.

However why do we even need to re-run the car/people cluster tests with all
apps installed? The point of the test suite is to test clustering
functionality with a specific yang model, as such we don't need 40+ other
apps installed to do that, especially since the "only" tests succeed.
Otherwise I'm afraid we're going to keep seeing intermittent failures due
to slower startup.

Hi All,

Per the discussion in last week's MD-SAL call, I have compiled a short list
of potential items the AAA team might discuss during the upcoming ODL
Developer's Forum at the end of the month.  This is by no means a promise
to deliver on these features, but more a way to advertise possible
improvements and align the community on plausible solutions.

1) Radius AAA Realm

- There are no known License-Friendly versions of Radius Client available.

- We may need to spin a lightweight Radius impl similar to [1]

2) Stabilize the MD-SAL Store Plugin

- Implicitly, this involves conversion of bundles from
Activator/BundleTracker(s) to Configuration Subsystem.  I have heard there
are possible efforts of moving away from this architecture, to something
like Aries Blueprint;  I think this is another good topic to bring up at
the Developer's Forum.

- [2] explains how to possibly speed up AAA MD-SAL Store Plugin loading.

3) Improvements to Authorization

- Clean up the AuthZ Broker Facade

- Allow applications to register themselves with AuthZBrokerFacade [3]

- Advanced filtering for models

This is by no means comprehensive, and is mostly just what I have derived
from open bugs and asks from the community.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

[1]
https://github.com/opennetworkinglab/onos/blob/master/apps/aaa/src/main/java/org/onosproject/aaa/AaaManager.java

[2] https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=4702

[3] https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=4159

[4] https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=2251

On Wed, Feb 24, 2016 at 12:30 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Hi Srini,

Two things to mention here:
1) *In Lithium the prerequisite was to specify domain as part of the
Authorization header*.  I.e., instead of doing:
curl -u alice:password
http://192.168.56.102:8181/restconf/operational/opendaylight-inventory:nodes
you would need to do:
curl -H "Authorization: Basic YWxpY2U6cGFzc3dvcmQ6YWxwaGFiZXQ="
http://192.168.56.102:8181/restconf/operational/opendaylight-inventory:nodes
where YWxpY2U6cGFzc3dvcmQ6YWxwaGFiZXQ= is base64( "alice:password:alphabet"
)

This is what I inherited as an existing interface when I became PTL of AAA,
which is technically not standards compliant.  Support for multi-tenancy is
still very weak in ODL (even if you specify a user belongs to a non-"sdn"
domain, it doesn't actually mean anything in the current implementation
since we don't do domain-based filtering on RESTCONF endpoints.  *This is
functionality that is on the table for Boron timeframe though!*

2) RESTCONF utilizes the new AAAFilter as of Beryllium, which assumes "sdn"
domain because multi-tenancy didn't actually lead to any functional gain.
As you point out, this is technically a bug, so I have submitted a bug [1]
and patch [2] to fix this behavior.  That said, assume that "domain" is
more of a placeholder without much functionality whatsoever in this
release.  Since adding the domain after a second colon is technically not
standards compliant for Basic Authorization, we will use the following
scheme:

curl -u admin at sdn:admin
http://192.168.56.102:8181/restconf/operational/opendaylight-inventory:nodes

If no "@domain" exists, the "sdn" default domain will be assumed for
backwards compatibility.  This should be merged soon and will be cherry
picked back into stable/beryllium.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

[1] https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=5425
[2] https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/35364

On Wed, Feb 24, 2016 at 3:42 PM, Srini Seetharaman <
srini.seetharaman at gmail.com> wrote:

Thanks Ryan.

Regarding #1: I have a slight correction. In Lithium, domain is ignored.
So, as long as the user name as unique across domains, there is no login
issue. But in Beryllium, the authentication pays attention to the domain.
So, a mistakenly assumed "sdn" domain will cause login failure. However,
using oauth tokens worked fine in the domain (i.e., scope) context and
let's me login with "bearer" auth mechanism.

Regarding the user:password:domain convention, I did figure from the code
that the request I must send should be "Basic
base64encode('alice:alice:alphabet')", but that actually doesn't work
either. When my curl sends out the following header,

* Connected to 192.168.56.102 (192.168.56.102) port 8181 (#0)
    GET /restconf/operational/opendaylight-inventory:nodes HTTP/1.1
    User-Agent: curl/7.35.0
    Host: 192.168.56.102:8181
    Accept: */*
    Authorization: Basic YWxpY2U6YWxpY2U6YWxwaGFiZXQ=

After some debugging, I see that the code in
org.apache.shiro.web.filter.authc.AuthenticatingFilter.executeLogin()
creates a token only using the userName and password field. So, the domain
is lost subsequently and the "sdn" domain is applied. This causes the login
failure because "alice" is not available in that domain.

Thanks for pushing a fix that will allow using "alice at alphabet" as the
username. This is generally acceptable convention and I'm glad it will be
cherry picked for Beryllium.

Can you clarify two more points:
1. What domain-based filtering on RESTCONF endpoints can we expect in Boron?
2. "...multi-tenancy didn't actually lead to any functional gain" in
Beryllium.

Srini.


On Wed, Feb 24, 2016 at 3:30 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:
Thanks Ryan.

The filtering in that example reflects the AuthZDOMDataBroker, which is
experimental.  It is essentially a Facade for the DOMDataBroker.

Shiro filtering examples are being added to the formal documentation, but
they are based on [1].  Shiro authorization is based on a web url pattern,
and a set of required roles.  In Beryllium, these rules don't have the
notion of domain, and they are meant for coarse grained RBAC.  A simple
example is to provide the following rule above "/** = authcBasic" in
shiro.ini:
/streams/ = authcBasic, roles[admin]

Then restart the controller.  This essentially sections of the "
http://localhost:8181/restconf/streams/" endpoint for users with the admin
role only.  Wildcards can be added (odl-aaa-authz got the wildcarded url
idea from Shiro, from what I have heard from past contributors).

It would've been better if the default case is "Deny" for all resources for

Rashmi,

How did you configure your JCE?  Did you disable bouncy castle in
custom.properties (comment it out) and just rely on the default JCE
Provider?  If so, then the default SUN Provider doesn't actually provide
that cipher;  you need to use SunJSSE (and Java 8 since it isn't a part of
Java 7 SunJSSE impl, but from your stack trace it looks like you are using
1.8.0_60 so that is good).  The provider ordering is specified in
"/usr/java/jdk1.8.0_65/jre/lib/security/java.security";  can you confirm
you are actually using SunJSSE?

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Tue, Mar 1, 2016 at 10:03 AM, Rashmi Pujar <rpujar at inocybe.ca> wrote:

Thanks for your reply Ryan. I did not edit the custom.properties to disable
BC provider. Should this be commented to ensure Sun provider will be used?
So far I was logging the provider of the SSLContext Object in the
openflowjava code to know the provider that was being used and it is "SUN
version 1.8 Provider". Looks like openflowjava uses the default Sun
provider. And that is how I used the cipher suite name to test.

Here is the provider ordering on my system:





*security.provider.1=sun.security.provider.Sunsecurity.provider.2=sun.security.rsa.SunRsaSignsecurity.provider.3=sun.security.ec.SunECsecurity.provider.4=com.sun.net.ssl.internal.ssl.Providersecurity.provider.5=com.sun.crypto.provider.SunJCEsecurity.provider.6=sun.security.jgss.SunProvider*

Hi Vishal,

The cert-provider functionality is still in its infancy;  master AAA now
includes the ability to generate keys.  However, we are not clustering them
or persisting them to the data store yet.  This is functionality that is in
our Boron release plan but has not been tackled yet;  I am sorry if you
were told differently.  It is a gap in ODL's current Beryllium
implementation.

As for setting up SSL for OVSDB, I have never done it.  I don't know
whether ODL's OVSDB currently supports setting up SSL/TLS... it has been
about 6 months since I have looked at the southbound code.  Sam, any
thoughts here?  I would have to imagine that you just place the keystore in
a well known location if the functionality exists.  That said, I am not
sure it was ever tackled...

Best Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Fri, Mar 11, 2016 at 6:22 AM, Vishal Thapar <vishal.thapar at ericsson.com>
wrote:

After re-reading this thread, it looks like ODL OVSDB does support
SSL/TLS.  Sam et. al, where does the keystore need to be located to get
picked up?  I'd imagine we just need to make sure the AAA key generation
code drops the keystore in the correct filesystem location...

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Fri, Mar 11, 2016 at 8:03 AM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Hi Ryan,

Srinivasa mentions in https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=5306 that support I OVSDB southbound is not complete and has also added some code to read certificate info off these, but such code doesn?t exist yet. Other than AAA, we will still need some configuration to enable/disable SSL support for Passive and active OVSDB connections. Active may require field in yang to specify SSL as a type for connection-info.

Sam,
So the question now is do we wait for AAA to be ready for use or do we put in some stop-gap code to support TLS/SSL? My interest in it comes from certain deployments/devices not allowing non-SSL connection to TOR devices. I think we need this support in Beryllium too.

Thoughts?

Regards,
Vishal.

On Fri, Mar 11, 2016 at 7:05 AM, Sam Hague <shague at redhat.com> wrote:

Ryan, How in general certification access works ? Do user need to register
the certificates per device and then southbound plugin can access the
certificates through AAA? Or there is some other architecture need to be in
place?

Just wondering if it make sense to have device specific certificates in
AAA, because OVSDB devices will be accessed only through southbound plugin,
so isn't it better to put them in southbound plugin itself? Until and
unless we want to put restriction on who can access these certificates,
that's where probably AAA comes to the picture, but in this case i don't
see any scenario. Thoughts ?

On Fri, Mar 11, 2016 at 5:05 AM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Hi Anil,

Deployments that require SSL for OVSDB will probably want to have SSL for OpenFlow too. This means we will need to use same certificate for OVSDB as well as OF. So I?d say still makes sense to have certificates in AAA and different applications can register with AAA to access those.

Regards,
Vishal.

Until and unless we want to put restriction on who can access these certificates, that's where probably AAA comes to the picture, but in this case i don't see any scenario. Thoughts ?

On Fri, Mar 11, 2016 at 10:05 AM, Sam Hague <shague at redhat.com> wrote:

Hi ovsdb team,

Just to explain how the certificate base authentication work, we have 2
possible architectures

1- Selfsign PKI for ODL: which mean the ODL will generate its private key
and certificate, then ODL will needs the certificate of each ovsdb-node to
be added to its keystore and the ovsdb-node can receive the ODL certificate
by allowing bootstrap in its SSL config

2- Hierarchical PKI for ODL: which mean the ODL will generate its private
key and Certificate Signing Request CSR. Then the ODL's CSR should be
signed by a CA  (Certificate Authority or  Intermediate Certificate
Authority) based on your structure. after the CA sign the ODL's CSR and
generate the ODL's certificate, the ODL's certificate should be added to
the ODL keystore and the ovsdb-node's certificate should be also signed by
the same CA  allow mutual authentication.

What we have now in aaa-cert ? the aaa-cert bundle support the 2
architectures we just mentioned above. Once the aaa-cert feature installed,
ODL will have its private key, certificate, CSR and establish a TLS
connection for the openflow protocol "based on openflowjava TLS
configuration".

Ovsdb project can use aaa-cert to do :
1- add the ovsdb-node certificate to the trust keystore
2- generate a CSR and then add the signed certificate to the ODL keystore
(if using Hierarchical PKI)
3- receive the  keystores that required to establish the SSL connection.

What is missing ? as Ryan mentioned all certificates and ODL private key
are stored in a Java keystore file not in mdsal, so there is no cluster
support, there is no way now to exchange the keystore across the cluster
nodes.
We are Working on this issue and I will propose something soon but cannot
guarantee it will be ready within 2 weeks.

So Ovsdb may can support TLS but for a single ODL node or manage in someway
to have the kestores copied across the ODL cluster nodes. Also have to
notice that openflowjava have the same issue there is no support for
openflow TLS communication across cluster nodes.  Hope this help to clarify
the issue

Thanks

correct, we could ensure that we collect heapdumps in all of our CSIT going forward,
and then collecting those as 2G or 3G artifacts.  As Luis questioned, can we store
that?  We will likely hit a point where something breaks and OOM is coming frequently
until the bug is fixed, and all 10's 100's of CSIT jobs that ran during that period
would be holding on to these large files.

On Thu, Mar 24, 2016 at 8:35 PM, Tom Pantelis <tompantelis at gmail.com> wrote:

We have a lot of smart people involved with this project who are pretty good at reading heap dumps ;).  I'd argue that taking heap dumps in OOM scenario is necessary (at least temporarily) so we can get an idea if there is a real issue, or if we actually do just require a lot of memory (that is certainly realistic too).  Call it Machiavellian but I'd trade off disk space to isolate the root cause (if there is one)... Even if it is just temporary.

Ryan

> XX:+HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError

Default values for java options
seem to be defined in controller project.
I have contributed a change [0] to enable this.

Note that even if heap is dumped,
the suite has to download it from ODL_SYSTEM
(perhaps compressing it beforehand),
and job has to archive it
(currently only files matching ?*.log*? are archived).

To save space and time, only few jobs should perform
the download and archive steps.
(An -all- job, and perhaps some scale tests.)

Vratko.

Hi Rosh,

In Beryllium-SR1, the you can enable debug on this class [1].  To enable
debug from karaf:

karaf> log:set DEBUG org.opendaylight.aaa.shiro.realm.TokenAuthRealm

The messaging is a bit vague, so it was improved in master
(Beryllium-SR2).  If you switch to that, there is an AuthenticationListener
impl [2] registered by default which reports this information at DEBUG
level.  In master, you can enable this logging by:

karaf> log:set DEBUG
org.opendaylight.aaa.shiro.filters.AuthenticationListener

Hope this helps!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

[1]
https://github.com/opendaylight/aaa/blob/29de5e12098bf706b8042f396f2a2c7c95f1ef41/aaa-shiro/src/main/java/org/opendaylight/aaa/shiro/realm/TokenAuthRealm.java
[2]
https://github.com/opendaylight/aaa/blob/master/aaa-shiro/src/main/java/org/opendaylight/aaa/shiro/filters/AuthenticationListener.java

On Wed, Apr 20, 2016 at 10:43 AM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Yes, this is most likely due to not having odl-restconf installed.
 odl-restconf installs odl-aaa-shiro, which does the file installation of
shiro.ini (through config statement in features.xml).  Since odl-restconf
was re-added, this should be fixed.

Thanks Sam and Tim for the additional info, it is greatly appreciated.
Please always feel free to reach out to aaa-dev with issues that you
encounter so we can make sure they are addressed and fixed ASAP!

Thanks,

Ryan Goulding

On Wed, Apr 20, 2016 at 11:12 AM, Tim Rozet <trozet at redhat.com> wrote:

but, this still doesn't explain why it's coming when we don't install the
ovsdb -ui feature? don't we want to get to the bottom of that also, even
if our current ovsdb-openstack is now fixed?

JamO

On 04/20/2016 08:16 AM, Ryan Goulding wrote:
On 04/20/2016 04:48 AM, Sam Hague wrote:

It looks like the ui version installs odl-mdsal-apidocs [1] (which brings
in restconf for free) [2].  You should install odl-restconf in the non-ui
version as well...

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

[1]
https://github.com/opendaylight/ovsdb/blob/45896ee74e59f5f3ec50ead6d93ce289fa78419d/southbound/southbound-features/src/main/features/features.xml
[2]
https://github.com/opendaylight/netconf/blob/master/features/restconf/src/main/features/features.xml

On Wed, Apr 20, 2016 at 11:25 AM, Jamo Luhrsen <jluhrsen at gmail.com> wrote:

I guess what I'm asking is why do we get the blow-up (FileNotFound Exceptions, etc) when we
don't bring in restconf?

JamO

On 04/20/2016 08:32 AM, Ryan Goulding wrote:
It sounds like you were blowing up without it:

Sorry reread this and I think I understand what you were asking a bit
better;  odl-restconf brings in that missing file shiro.ini (really
odl-aaa-shiro installs it, and odl-restconf installs odl-aaa-shiro).  Since
odl-restconf was never installed, shiro.ini was never deployed.  What it
really boils down to is;  if you try to use odl-restconf without expressing
dependency on it, things aren't going to work out so great.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Wed, Apr 20, 2016 at 11:41 AM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

All,

just had an IRC session with Ryan.  Looks like the root problem here is that
neutron (and gbp) is still depending on a deprecated aaa features (authn).
Ryan can give more gory details if anyone is interested, and he's giving
patches now.

In the end, putting restconf back in to our openstack feature was needed (so
the trouble would not have been seen), but we did end up finding two projects
to fix.

Thanks,
JamO

On 04/20/2016 08:47 AM, Ryan Goulding wrote:

In short, gbp and neutron were using a deprecated AAA Filter that wasn't
pulling in the required servlet runtime dependencies.  I have submitted [1]
and [2] to upgrade them to the correct Filter.

Thanks,

Ryan Goulding

[1] https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/37931/
[2] https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/37935/

Text:
Hi,

Currently it's not supported, that's why there is only the login-password case present in the model.
Bug to track this: https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=5817
I don't want to make any commitments but we might be able to tackle this by the end of Boron if we have spare resources.

Tomas

On Wed, Apr 27, 2016 at 11:33 AM, Ferran Quer i Guerrero <ferran.quer at i2cat.net<mailto:ferran.quer at i2cat.net>> wrote:
Hello everyone,

I want to control some netconf-enabled switches with OpenDaylight that
require asymetric crypto for authentication, via ssh "identity file".
However, the restconf node model doesn't seem to accept any auth method
other than user-password one.

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/opendaylight/netconf/3062d9b5a6704075b4b10a8e1ad481738ca370c7/netconf/sal-netconf-connector/src/main/yang/netconf-node-topology.yang

    grouping netconf-node-credentials {

        choice credentials {
            config true;
            case login-password {
                leaf username {
                    type string;
                }

                leaf password {
                    type string;
                }
            }
        }
    }

I have seen in your repository that you implement federated
authentication to OpenDaylight and many other features, but I'm unsure
if and equivalent module to password credentials for public key is
already available. In that case, I would try to use it from netconf
modules. Otherwise, is it on the roadmap?

Thank you for your time,
Ferran

Text:
Hi Mohamed,
I already knew those wiki entries, they are really helpful.

El 28/04/16 a les 18:38, Mohamed ElSerngawy ha escrit:

Hi AAA,

any idea on these system test failures?  Nothing stands out in karaf.log or
the actual test suite logs.  Looks like trouble with auth tokens.  Two
jobs with latest SR2 each had a single failure, though not the same failure:

https://jenkins.opendaylight.org/releng/job/aaa-csit-1node-authn-only-beryllium/1248/robot/report/log.html
https://jenkins.opendaylight.org/releng/job/aaa-csit-1node-authn-only-beryllium/1253/robot/report/log.html

Both failures are same basic reason.  The suite gets a token and then
tries to use it when hitting /restconf/modules and expects a 200 status
code, but gets 401 instead.

There were no AAA CSIT failure in the previous SR2 distro.

Thanks,
JamO

On 05/03/2016 01:19 PM, An Ho wrote:

I spoke to someone else on your team and expressed that this has already
been added in Boron and is part of Beryllium-SR2.  The log messages are
suppressed by default to avoid superfluous logging.  To enable this
logging, just issue the following from karaf:

karaf> log:set DEBUG org.opendaylight.aaa.shiro.filters

This functionality is included in the AuthenticationListener class here [1].

Hope this helps!


Regards,

Ryan Goulding

[1]
https://github.com/opendaylight/aaa/blob/master/aaa-shiro/src/main/java/org/opendaylight/aaa/shiro/filters/AuthenticationListener.java

On Tue, May 17, 2016 at 4:32 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

At a high level, I think that your first concern comes down to the fact
that you feel like the definition of what a feature has to do to be stable
isn't strong enough. Given that we've been at this for 3 years, have no
stable features and the dominant complaint we have is that the requirements
for a feature to be stable are too high, I'm just going to have to disagree
and say maybe we should either (a) have a stronger label for the form of
API stability you talk about or (b) increase the requirements to be stable
over time as we can more reasonably meet thme.

In terms of the definition of a feature, I *think* we specified it to be
the set of bundles that feature pulls in and that the features it pulls in
must also be stable. It probably needs to be refined a little bit to say
that it should transitively include the set of bundles it pulls in local to
this project. I'd be happy to work through what we think a reasonable
concrete definition was. My hope was that this would be something that
could be eyeballed (by the TSC) at the beginning and codified (or not) as
we gained experience.

In terms of longevity, runtime compatibility and ABI compatibility, I think
I'll come to the same point as I did on your first concern. Interesting
ideas, but I think not moving forward with some notion of stability because
we don't have these is throwing the baby out with the bathwater.

--Colin

Moving forward we want to attempt to maintain a clean distribution-test job [0],
which is our jenkins project that runs many of our system test (CSIT) jobs.  Some
details about this job:

- This is run with every distribution autorelease produces.
- It is the job we use as the Integration team to discern the quality of release
  candidates.
- Can be used to test gerrit patches, using the "test-integration" keyword [1]

We also envision downstream consumers (e.g. OPNFV) being able to quickly check these
results when determining if they can consume a nightly distribution or if it may be
broken in some way.  This can be a valuable piece toward moving to faster release
cycles, as well.

In order to maximize the benefit of this job, we need all CSIT jobs running
there to adhere to our system test case expectations [2].

So, in the short term we have removed [3][4] all projects' (see list above
for affected projects) CSIT jobs that are not meeting these expectations.
Having CSIT jobs running there is a release requirement [5] in order to
avoid features being labeled as experimental, so although the current number
of CSIT jobs may be low in our Boron distribution test job, I expect that
projects will start to bring their CSIT jobs to a more reliable state and
then introduce them back (or for the first time) via this job .yaml [6]

Please reach out to the Integration team if you have any questions.

Thanks,
JamO

[0] https://jenkins.opendaylight.org/releng/view/Distribution-Jobs/job/integration-distribution-test-beryllium/
[1] https://opendaylight.readthedocs.io/en/latest/submodules/releng/builder/docs/jenkins.html#patch-test-job
[2] https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/Integration/Test/Test_Case_Expectations
[3] https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/39453/
[4] https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/39451
[5] https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/CrossProject:Integration_Group:Boron_Traditional_Release_Project_Integration_Requirements#system_test
[6] https://github.com/opendaylight/releng-builder/blob/master/jjb/integration/integration-test-jobs.yaml

On Wed, Jun 29, 2016 at 12:34 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

(...) services likely just hadn't loaded yet...

Brady,

Checking back in on this one to make sure you aren't still experiencing
issues?  AAA service resolution is punted to a separate thread (a
ServiceTrackerCustomizer) that sometimes takes a little bit of time to come
up.  In the situation that RESTCONF loads prior to AAA, you will see 401.
That is simply because the service isn't yet available, and there is no way
to derive whether credentials are any good.  In this way, AAA is a
fail-closed system;  we do not want to let people in just because the
services haven't loaded.  Perhaps it would be more useful to report a 5XX
code during this time period?  I am sorry the messaging about this is
ambiguous.

There were plans to migrate to blueprint, but those fell off the radar thus
far.  We are still hoping to get this in sometime in the Boron timeframe.
What this means is that we could force a more deterministic ordering to
ensure AAA services are injected prior to RESTCONF.

Please let me know if you continue experiencing issues with AAA.  I am more
than happy to inspect jstack and karaf logs if so;  we have put in a bunch
of useful information to track AAA service injection state over the past
few releases to help track "is it up" for AAA anyway.  As far as I know
things should be working well on the AAA front.  Let me know if you find
otherwise!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

From: Mohamed ElSerngawy [mailto:melserngawy at inocybe.ca]
Sent: 14 March 2016 06:56
To: Sam Hague <shague at redhat.com>
Cc: Vishal Thapar <vishal.thapar at ericsson.com>; Anil Vishnoi <vishnoianil at gmail.com>; Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>; <ovsdb-dev at lists.opendaylight.org> <ovsdb-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>; aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; Srinivasa Tagirisa <srinivasa at wildfire.exchange>
Subject: Re: [ovsdb-dev] TLS support and certificates

Hi ovsdb team,

Just to explain how the certificate base authentication work, we have 2 possible architectures

1- Selfsign PKI for ODL: which mean the ODL will generate its private key and certificate, then ODL will needs the certificate of each ovsdb-node to be added to its keystore and the ovsdb-node can receive the ODL certificate by allowing bootstrap in its SSL config

2- Hierarchical PKI for ODL: which mean the ODL will generate its private key and Certificate Signing Request CSR. Then the ODL's CSR should be signed by a CA  (Certificate Authority or  Intermediate Certificate Authority) based on your structure. after the CA sign the ODL's CSR and generate the ODL's certificate, the ODL's certificate should be added to the ODL keystore and the ovsdb-node's certificate should be also signed by the same CA  allow mutual authentication.

What we have now in aaa-cert ? the aaa-cert bundle support the 2 architectures we just mentioned above. Once the aaa-cert feature installed, ODL will have its private key, certificate, CSR and establish a TLS connection for the openflow protocol "based on openflowjava TLS configuration".

Ovsdb project can use aaa-cert to do :
1- add the ovsdb-node certificate to the trust keystore
2- generate a CSR and then add the signed certificate to the ODL keystore (if using Hierarchical PKI)
3- receive the  keystores that required to establish the SSL connection.

What is missing ? as Ryan mentioned all certificates and ODL private key are stored in a Java keystore file not in mdsal, so there is no cluster support, there is no way now to exchange the keystore across the cluster nodes.
We are Working on this issue and I will propose something soon but cannot guarantee it will be ready within 2 weeks.

So Ovsdb may can support TLS but for a single ODL node or manage in someway to have the kestores copied across the ODL cluster nodes. Also have to notice that openflowjava have the same issue there is no support for openflow TLS communication across cluster nodes.  Hope this help to clarify the issue

Thanks

As for setting up SSL for OVSDB, I have never done it.  I don't know whether ODL's OVSDB currently supports setting up SSL/TLS... it has been about 6 months since I have looked at the southbound code.  Sam, any thoughts here?  I would have to imagine that you just place the keystore in a well known location if the functionality exists.  That said, I am not sure it was ever tackled...

Best Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Subject: Re: [ovsdb-dev] TLS support and certificates

Hi ovsdb team,

Just to explain how the certificate base authentication work, we have 2 possible architectures

1- Selfsign PKI for ODL: which mean the ODL will generate its private key and certificate, then ODL will needs the certificate of each ovsdb-node to be added to its keystore and the ovsdb-node can receive the ODL certificate by allowing bootstrap in its SSL config

2- Hierarchical PKI for ODL: which mean the ODL will generate its private key and Certificate Signing Request CSR. Then the ODL's CSR should be signed by a CA  (Certificate Authority or  Intermediate Certificate Authority) based on your structure. after the CA sign the ODL's CSR and generate the ODL's certificate, the ODL's certificate should be added to the ODL keystore and the ovsdb-node's certificate should be also signed by the same CA  allow mutual authentication.

What we have now in aaa-cert ? the aaa-cert bundle support the 2 architectures we just mentioned above. Once the aaa-cert feature installed, ODL will have its private key, certificate, CSR and establish a TLS connection for the openflow protocol "based on openflowjava TLS configuration".

Ovsdb project can use aaa-cert to do :
1- add the ovsdb-node certificate to the trust keystore
2- generate a CSR and then add the signed certificate to the ODL keystore (if using Hierarchical PKI)
3- receive the  keystores that required to establish the SSL connection.

What is missing ? as Ryan mentioned all certificates and ODL private key are stored in a Java keystore file not in mdsal, so there is no cluster support, there is no way now to exchange the keystore across the cluster nodes.
We are Working on this issue and I will propose something soon but cannot guarantee it will be ready within 2 weeks.

So Ovsdb may can support TLS but for a single ODL node or manage in someway to have the kestores copied across the ODL cluster nodes. Also have to notice that openflowjava have the same issue there is no support for openflow TLS communication across cluster nodes.  Hope this help to clarify the issue

Thanks

On Sat, Jul 9, 2016 at 7:33 AM, Vishal Thapar <vishal.thapar at ericsson.com>
wrote:

Hi Jan,

Good questions.  AAA is implemented as a set of OSGi services, and is local
per node.  The default TokenAuthRealm is *not* cluster aware in the default
implementation, though I would like to see that change (would be a good
place to utilize new EOS APIs Vaclav and Robert have been working on).  The
backing data store is based on a simple H2 SQL implementation (file based),
and is distinct per node.  Each node has its own set of database
credentials, which must be synchronized using out of band means.  This
isn't a great design, but it has provided necessary functionality so far.
It is suggested to use The ODLJndiLdapRealm for clustered scenarios, which
essentially punts auth decisions to an external LDAP server.

And does it support high-availability?


If the AAA service fails on a particular node, that node is hosed.  The
other two nodes are still usable.  This has been sufficient thus far, but
we really ought to re-examine this in Carbon.

AAA contribution has been fairly low over the past release unfortunately,
so this is our unfortunate status quo.  As I said before, my motivation is
somewhat limited since we recommend to use LDAP for clustered scenarios.
That said, if you or others have cycles to contribute, I can certainly
provide assistance.

Hope this helps!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

From: aaa-dev-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org <aaa-dev-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org> on behalf of Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
Sent: Monday, July 18, 2016 11:00 AM

Cc: aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [Aaa-dev] AAA module cluster-aware?

Hi Jan,

Good questions.  AAA is implemented as a set of OSGi services, and is local per node.  The default TokenAuthRealm is not cluster aware in the default implementation, though I would like to see that change (would be a good place to utilize new EOS APIs Vaclav and Robert have been working on).  The backing data store is based on a simple H2 SQL implementation (file based), and is distinct per node.  Each node has its own set of database credentials, which must be synchronized using out of band means.  This isn't a great design, but it has provided necessary functionality so far.  It is suggested to use The ODLJndiLdapRealm for clustered scenarios, which essentially punts auth decisions to an external LDAP server.

And does it support high-availability?

If the AAA service fails on a particular node, that node is hosed.  The other two nodes are still usable.  This has been sufficient thus far, but we really ought to re-examine this in Carbon.

AAA contribution has been fairly low over the past release unfortunately, so this is our unfortunate status quo.  As I said before, my motivation is somewhat limited since we recommend to use LDAP for clustered scenarios.  That said, if you or others have cycles to contribute, I can certainly provide assistance.

Hope this helps!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Hi Muthu,

These are currently stored per node in a file based database (idmlight.db.mv.db).  You can manipulate the credentials using the utility script called idmtool (which is installed to the etc folder upon feature installation).

2.      In order to use shiro.ini , is odl-restconf-all feature alone is sufficient  or any other additional features to be installed ?

Yes, odl-restconf automatically installs the odl-aaa-shiro feature.  That is all that is needed.

3.      In distro ZIP I am not able to find shiro.ini etc folder. Does this get placed at etc folder only when we bring up controller at least once and/or only when required features are installed ?

Upon feature installation.  If AAA is not needed, the file doesn't need to be installed.  It was also quite a bit easier than doing the artifact copy at built time in the integration/distribution project.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Unfortunately, we do not currently have federation with Keystone;  there
was a feature that someone had contributed a very long time ago called
"odl-aaa-keystone", but that was removed as it was not actually implemented.

Federation with an existing LDAP IdP exists, and is documented right inside
shiro.ini;  you must make the changes to shiro.ini on each node in a
clustered setup.  We wrap the out of the box Shiro ODLJndiLdapRealm
implementation, which basically just wraps the Jndi implementation.  I have
set it up several times using my company's IdP as well as FreeIPA.  Please
let me know if you have any questions setting it up!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

From: dev-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org [mailto:dev-bounces at lists.opendaylight.org] On Behalf Of Ryan Goulding
Sent: Friday, July 29, 2016 7:45 PM
To: Andre Fredette <afredette at redhat.com>
Cc: ODL Dev <odl-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>; aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: [opendaylight-dev] what are the default user name and password for current ODL UI?

Yi,

The credentials are still the same;  the Shiro framework was included since it is an excellent framework to federate with many 3rd party IdP systems.  May I ask what HTTP response code you received when trying to log in?  You can see this by using:

curl -v -u admin:admin http://localhost:8181/restconf/steams

I am thinking the controller was still booting, which is why your auth attempt fails (odl-mdsal-apidocs simply loaded before aaa bundles).

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Fri, Jul 29, 2016 at 7:26 AM, Andre Fredette <afredette at redhat.com<mailto:afredette at redhat.com>> wrote:

Andre

Hello AAA,

I'm working with the OPNFV Release Manager (David, CC'd) and
the OPNFV Moon project PTL (Ruan, CC'd) to upstream their fork
of OpenDaylight AAA.

They have a copy of AAA's repo, based off of Beryllium SR2, in
their OPNFV repo. They would like to get their changes proposed
against the upstream AAA repo, and eventually merged into AAA.

https://git.opnfv.org/cgit/moon/tree/odl-aaa-moon

I guess the first step is to rebase their changes into AAA. I
can imagine a number of mechanical ways to do that, but in general
we'd figure out what changes they made to AAA (git log/format-patch),
copy those changes into AAA's upstream repo and push a new Gerrit
to start the review discussion.

Ruan isn't experienced with contributing to upstream communities,
so I would really appreciate help to make this minimally painful.

Who wants to do the git-foo to create a Gerrit from their changes?

Daniel Farrell
Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/user:dfarrell07

Hi Daniel & Ruan,

First of all, thanks for the introduction to some of the OPNFV guys!  AAA
team appreciates contribution from all contributors, and I am glad to see
other organizations are looking through our code base.  That said I do have
a few things that I'd like to state in the friendliest way possible:

1) This is essentially a fork right now, which is expressly discouraged by
EPL;  it lives separate from the rest of the AAA development process.
2) Large changes are often difficult and time consuming to review and merge
conflicts can be hard to resolve over time.

These things aren't insurmountable, and I am sure we can get through them.
Ruan, do you have a high level description of the changes that you made?
This would be super helpful to determine which functionality is affected.

My recommendation is for Ruan to move his changes into a branch based off
*master* and to add myself, Sharon Aichler and Mohamed El'Serngawy to the
review.  Since new functionality is reserved for major releases, it is
easiest to get this into the Boron stream.  If Ruan needs a bit of help
porting the code, I am more than happy to try to provide assistance.

Thanks,

Ryan Goulding

On Fri, Aug 5, 2016 at 11:13 AM, Daniel Farrell <dfarrell at redhat.com> wrote:

Sounds like a cool feature;  I know many people have wanted to use
OpenStack as and IdP for ODL in the past.  I am adding Phil Robb (Director
of Networking Solutions at The Linux Foundation) and my colleague Colin
Dixon (Technical Steering Chairman) to ensure that everything is kosher in
terms of intellectual property for moving this code into OpenDaylight AAA.
While I realize you have a fork of our code, it appears to be located in an
OPNFV repository;  I generally delegate these types of questions to higher
ups who have more familiarity with licensing :).

Could you provide the the command I could use to clone your OPNFV upstream
git repository?  I would like to see what the changes look like in a
non-browser view.

Thanks!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Fri, Aug 5, 2016 at 4:01 PM, <ruan.he at orange.com> wrote:

Hi Ryan,
Thanks a lot for your reply, since we are new in this community, this issue becomes an important lesson for us!! Our future contribution will strictly follow your recommendation!!
My colleague, Alioune BA, has contacted you previously for the Moon/OPNFV project. Our objective is to delegate ODL?s authentication to OpenStack/Keystone, which enables unique identification for OPNFV. As you can see in the figure prepared by Alioune, the main changes that we have made for AAA are:

-          A new filter in Shiro

-          A new Moon AuthN Realm for token

-          An authenticator that redirects authentication request to OpenStack/Keystone-moon and returns the UUID of the user in OpenStack.

[cid:image003.png at 01D1EF64.EC7CE070]

Thanks,
Ruan HE

Hi Mohamed,

Looks like they implemented a custom AuthenticatingFilter and Realm (shiro
APIs), which is a good approach for our architecture.  You likely enable it

within the shiro context.  Agreed, documentation in form of a wiki article
would be super useful.

I remember recommending a similar approach a while back to one of Ruan's
colleagues, Alioune, but hadn't heard back in a while.  Glad to see this
coming to fruition.

Ryan Goulding

On 08/10/2016 09:07 AM, Ryan Goulding wrote:

Ack thanks, that's what I was looking for!

Sent from my iPhone

Ryan,

OPNFV is primarily about integration, deployment, and test.  Although some
projects generate new code, most projects generate changes to upstream
components in order to fill gaps or to measure or improve performance.

The OPNFV release vehicle is what we call a "scenario", which is more or
less a use case made up of an installer, a set of components, and a
configuration.  Scenarios have installation guides and other documentation
that describe how to setup and deploy the scenario.  Scenarios also have a
set of test cases implemented using the OPNFV test frameworks FuncTest and
Yardstick that run as part of CI.

David

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20160812/2ef60317/attachment.html>

Have you tried the default userDnTemplate?

ldapRealm.userDnTemplate = uid={0},ou=People,dc=*DOMAIN*,dc=*TLD*

replacing only the *bolded* parts with the values appropriate for your
scenario?

For example:
ldapRealm.userDnTemplate = uid={0},ou=People,dc=brocade,dc=com

This has worked very successfully for me in the past for OpenLDAP
deployments.  Which IdP are you using?


Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Fri, Aug 12, 2016 at 11:01 AM, Mohamed ElSerngawy <melserngawy at inocybe.ca

Hi Ryan,

There is no People organization "ou=People" in my LDAP setup so I guess it
will not gonna work also the uid is different.
I'm using OpenLDAP with ubuntu environment following [1] to setup. is there
a specific OpenLdap version should I use?

Thanks

[1] https://help.ubuntu.com/lts/serverguide/openldap-server.html

On Fri, Aug 12, 2016 at 11:37 AM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

You can just omit the ou=People like this:

ldapRealm.userDnTemplate = uid={0},dc=*DOMAIN*,dc=*TLD*

Otherwise, if you have a separate ou then you can substitute that:

ldapRealm.userDnTemplate = uid={0},ou=*YOUR_OU*,dc=*DOMAIN*,dc=*COM*

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-dependency-plugin:2.6:tree (default-cli) on project distribution-karaf: Execution default-cli of goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-dependency-plugin:2.6:tree failed: A required class was missing while executing org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-dependency-plugin:2.6:tree:

All credit goes to Thanh for the analysis and patch fixing the issues.  Many thanks for taking a look.

We would like to kindly remind projects not to override the dependency plugin version in odlparent.

Best Regards,
An Ho

Hi Ryan,

My colleague, Alioune BA, has contacted you previously for the Moon/OPNFV project. Our objective is to delegate ODL?s authentication to OpenStack/Keystone, which enables unique identification for OPNFV. As you can see in the figure prepared by Alioune, the main changes that we have made for AAA are:

-          A new filter in Shiro

-          A new Moon AuthN Realm for token

-          An authenticator that redirects authentication request to OpenStack/Keystone-moon and returns the UUID of the user in OpenStack.

Sent: vendredi 5 ao?t 2016 19:13

Subject: Re: Upstreaming OPNFV Moon to AAA

Hi Daniel & Ruan,

First of all, thanks for the introduction to some of the OPNFV guys!  AAA team appreciates contribution from all contributors, and I am glad to see other organizations are looking through our code base.  That said I do have a few things that I'd like to state in the friendliest way possible:

1) This is essentially a fork right now, which is expressly discouraged by EPL;  it lives separate from the rest of the AAA development process.
2) Large changes are often difficult and time consuming to review and merge conflicts can be hard to resolve over time.

These things aren't insurmountable, and I am sure we can get through them.  Ruan, do you have a high level description of the changes that you made?  This would be super helpful to determine which functionality is affected.

My recommendation is for Ruan to move his changes into a branch based off master and to add myself, Sharon Aichler and Mohamed El'Serngawy to the review.  Since new functionality is reserved for major releases, it is easiest to get this into the Boron stream.  If Ruan needs a bit of help porting the code, I am more than happy to try to provide assistance.

Thanks,

Ryan Goulding

On Fri, Aug 5, 2016 at 11:13 AM, Daniel Farrell <dfarrell at redhat.com<mailto:dfarrell at redhat.com>> wrote:
Hello AAA,

I'm working with the OPNFV Release Manager (David, CC'd) and
the OPNFV Moon project PTL (Ruan, CC'd) to upstream their fork
of OpenDaylight AAA.

They have a copy of AAA's repo, based off of Beryllium SR2, in
their OPNFV repo. They would like to get their changes proposed
against the upstream AAA repo, and eventually merged into AAA.

https://git.opnfv.org/cgit/moon/tree/odl-aaa-moon

I guess the first step is to rebase their changes into AAA. I
can imagine a number of mechanical ways to do that, but in general
we'd figure out what changes they made to AAA (git log/format-patch),
copy those changes into AAA's upstream repo and push a new Gerrit
to start the review discussion.

Ruan isn't experienced with contributing to upstream communities,
so I would really appreciate help to make this minimally painful.

Who wants to do the git-foo to create a Gerrit from their changes?

Daniel Farrell
Software Engineer, Red Hat SDN Team
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/user:dfarrell07
