For the AAA release review Monday morning, I have the following analysis of their
upstream CSIT for boron, using the most recent boron job result.

please note that I do not know if all delivered features have system test or not, so
only reporting on what exists.


OK        aaa-csit-1node-authn-all-boron    (intermittent failure due to ssh test infra issue)
OK        aaa-csit-1node-authn-only-boron   (well known bug 5838 cause intermittent failures)

NOT-OK    aaa-csit-1node-idmlite-only-boron (unexpected failures)
NOT-OK    aaa-csit-1node-idmlite-all-boron  (unexpected failures)

With these results, I think any idmlite related feature would be experimental.  Authn features
are ok.  All other AAA features delivered in Boron would also be experimental.


Thanks,
JamO

You are mixing two different models here;  the existing idmlight one
(default one) and the md-sal based model (not default).  I wouldn't use the
first method (the one using api doc explorer).

Instead, I would use python etc/idmtool as I said before.  It will change
the relevant information in the backing idmlight datastore.

Thanks,

Ryan

On Tue, Sep 20, 2016 at 12:40 PM, Nisha Verma1 <nisha.verma1 at tcs.com> wrote:

Hi Nisha,

Were you able to locate the idmtool script?

To add a bit of background info, the md-sal model is disabled by default
mainly because it was subject to some unexpectedly long waits (almost
deadlock like) scenarios in terms of bundle loading.  We have since
upgraded our DI framework to use Aries Blueprint, and may want to
investigate this approach again in Carbon.  One other reason is that, while
the passwords were encrypted, some of the other identity information was
presented in plain text through RESTCONF, which is a security concern for
many people.

HTH!


Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Hi Nisha,

You don't need to install odl-aaa-mdsal-cluster or odl-aaa-authz, just
install odl-restconf-all feature it will internally install odl-aaa-shiro,
odl-aaa-authn and odl-aaa-api.  For using the idmtool  just run* $ pyhton
idmtool -h* it will show you the usage.

Thanks

-----Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com> wrote: -----
To: Nisha Verma1 <nisha.verma1 at tcs.com>
From: Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>

Subject: Re: Issue while changing account passwords in ODL using AAA feature

Hi Nisha,

Were you able to locate the idmtool script?

To add a bit of background info, the md-sal model is disabled by default mainly because it was subject to some unexpectedly long waits (almost deadlock like) scenarios in terms of bundle loading.? We have since upgraded our DI framework to use Aries Blueprint, and may want to investigate this approach again in Carbon.? One other reason is that, while the passwords were encrypted, some of the other identity information was presented in plain text through RESTCONF, which is a security concern for many people.

HTH!


Regards,

Ryan Goulding
 
On Tue, Sep 20, 2016 at 12:52 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com> wrote:
You are mixing two different models here; ?the existing idmlight one (default one) and the md-sal based model (not default).? I wouldn't use the first method (the one using api doc explorer).

Instead, I would use python etc/idmtool as I said before.? It will change the relevant information in the backing idmlight datastore.

Thanks,

Ryan

On Mon, Sep 19, 2016 at 4:19 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com> wrote:
Also, you shouldn't use the psql method anymore, as stated on the wiki.? That method doesn't work well anymore since passwords are now encrypted.? Thus, you would need to pass the encrypted value to the update command.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding
 
On Mon, Sep 19, 2016 at 4:18 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com> wrote:
As I already said on the bug earlier, you can use idmtool.? It is located at "etc/idmtool" relative to the karaf home directory.? That will also show you how to do it using the rest endpoints since all idmtool does is wrap rest in a convenient CLI format.

Thanks,

Ryan Goulding

From: Ryan Goulding [mailto:ryandgoulding at gmail.com]
Sent: vendredi 7 octobre 2016 02:14
To: BA Alioune OBS/OAB
Cc: Mohamed El-Serngawy; HE Ruan IMT/OLPS; aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org
Subject: Re: Change in aaa[master]: AAA Moon Authentication Module support

Hi Alioune,

I would suggest to set the format of moonAuthRealm.moonServerURL in shiro.ini like http://<address>:<port<http://%3caddress%3e:%3cport>> because <address>:<port> leads to te error below at the install of odl-aaa-shiro
This is a fix we can definitely get in;  thanks for the feedback.  I will form a patch to modify the shiro.ini file tomorrow, as it is past 8 p.m. my local time now :).


After shutting down the karaf container and then running "rm -rf data/ snapshots/ journal/ etc/shiro.ini", I observed that the modified shiro.ini is not loaded in karaf/target/assembly/etc/ Is it the expected behavior ?

Yes, the shiro.ini file is loaded upon feature install.  If etc/shiro.ini does not exist, it is replaced by the default one (the one we modified in source).  If you want to keep the existing shiro.ini, just dont delete it (we don't overwrite by default).  When I tested your patch, I kept a copy in my home directory and copied it in as needed.

 I've successfully tested the patch [1] with OPNFV/moon with the above suggestion.

Awesome, thanks for your hard work and persistence!  We hope you will remain active as a contributor to the AAA project;  great work on your first contribution! I extend kind thanks to Ruan, and the rest of the OPNFV team involved on creating this patch;  lets hope this is not the only instance where we can form some project synergy :).

Kind Regards,

Ryan

Objet : Change in aaa[master]: AAA Moon Authentication Module support

Hi,

I am working on couple of requirements that need me to use\customize AAA.
I was going through the aaa documentation (ODL) and also apache shiro
documentation.

I have a question regarding shiro AuthenticationListener..

1. If I would like to add a custom AuthenticationListener, similar to the
one org.opendaylight.aaa.shiro.filters.AuthenticationListener for logging
purpose, how do i get my custom class into the classpath? the way I see
feat7res-restconf  depends on features-aaa-shiro. I want to add another
bundle, but how do I get this recognized by shiro.ini?


Thanks
hari

Hi Hari,

Is this something you are planning to add upstream?  If so, then you can
just put it in the  aaa-shiro bundle [1].

Otherwise, I suspect you would need to dynamically import the package for
use.

Hope this helps!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Subject: Re: Issue while changing account passwords in ODL using AAA feature

Hi Nisha,

Were you able to locate the idmtool script?

To add a bit of background info, the md-sal model is disabled by default mainly because it was subject to some unexpectedly long waits (almost deadlock like) scenarios in terms of bundle loading.? We have since upgraded our DI framework to use Aries Blueprint, and may want to investigate this approach again in Carbon.? One other reason is that, while the passwords were encrypted, some of the other identity information was presented in plain text through RESTCONF, which is a security concern for many people.

HTH!


Regards,

Ryan Goulding
 
On Tue, Sep 20, 2016 at 12:52 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com> wrote:
You are mixing two different models here; ?the existing idmlight one (default one) and the md-sal based model (not default).? I wouldn't use the first method (the one using api doc explorer).

Instead, I would use python etc/idmtool as I said before.? It will change the relevant information in the backing idmlight datastore.

Thanks,

Ryan

All of this is included in the upstream documentation [0].  Shiro based
LDAP is configured through etc/shiro.ini (the actual file explains how to
enable it as well).  LDAP can also be implemented using federation with an
Apache HTTP server [1].  I prefer the first approach since there is less
overhead in avoiding running a separate apache instance, but both should
work.

Hope this helps!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

[0]
http://docs.opendaylight.org/en/stable-boron/user-guide/authentication-and-authorization-services.html?highlight=AAA
[1] https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/AAA:Setting_Up_Federation

Subject: Re: Issue while changing account passwords in ODL using AAA feature

Hi Nisha,

Were you able to locate the idmtool script?

To add a bit of background info, the md-sal model is disabled by default mainly because it was subject to some unexpectedly long waits (almost deadlock like) scenarios in terms of bundle loading.? We have since upgraded our DI framework to use Aries Blueprint, and may want to investigate this approach again in Carbon.? One other reason is that, while the passwords were encrypted, some of the other identity information was presented in plain text through RESTCONF, which is a security concern for many people.

HTH!


Regards,

Ryan Goulding
 
On Tue, Sep 20, 2016 at 12:52 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com> wrote:
You are mixing two different models here; ?the existing idmlight one (default one) and the md-sal based model (not default).? I wouldn't use the first method (the one using api doc explorer).

Instead, I would use python etc/idmtool as I said before.? It will change the relevant information in the backing idmlight datastore.

Thanks,

Ryan

Subject: Re: Issue while changing account passwords in ODL using AAA feature

Hi Nisha,

Were you able to locate the idmtool script?

To add a bit of background info, the md-sal model is disabled by default mainly because it was subject to some unexpectedly long waits (almost deadlock like) scenarios in terms of bundle loading.? We have since upgraded our DI framework to use Aries Blueprint, and may want to investigate this approach again in Carbon.? One other reason is that, while the passwords were encrypted, some of the other identity information was presented in plain text through RESTCONF, which is a security concern for many people.

HTH!


Regards,

Ryan Goulding
 
On Tue, Sep 20, 2016 at 12:52 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com> wrote:
You are mixing two different models here; ?the existing idmlight one (default one) and the md-sal based model (not default).? I wouldn't use the first method (the one using api doc explorer).

Instead, I would use python etc/idmtool as I said before.? It will change the relevant information in the backing idmlight datastore.

Thanks,

Ryan

Did you grant your user a role?

python etc/idmtool admin add-grant <userid> <roleid>

For example, to add a grant for the user "ryan at sdn" for the role "admin at sdn
":

python etc/idmtool admin add-grant *ryan*@sdn *admin*@sdn


Hope this helps.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

unless you are looking to fork ODL, which is expressly prohibited by EPL.

I would suggest using OSGI's dynamic import functionality.

On Fri, Nov 4, 2016 at 12:02 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Yeah dynamic imports are sort of cool; they are fairly inefficient
classloader wise but a good/necessary way to retrofit existing OSGI
software.  I've done this a number of times for various bundles, so let me
know if you run into issues or need some guidance.  We may need to modify
the shiro maven-bundle-plugin configuration if things don't work using just
the karaf "bundle:dynamic-import" command.  This is the path I suggest if
you do not want to build directly into the aaa code base.  However, we are
always looking for new contributors and contributions ;).

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Hi Ryan,
We had spoke about this a couple times over IRC, and I think Michael wants to start looking into the work required to make this happen.  To recap there should be a way on the localhost running ODL to configure username/passwords/roles without using REST or knowing the admin password.  I think we can directly configure the database for most values, except for passwords - which you mentioned were salted.  So from my perspective this is one way to solve it:

1.  Make the java code which salts the passwords a runnable jar.
2.  Modify idmtool to allow direct configuration of the local DB, and have it call #1 when passwords are created/modified.

Thoughts?  Here is the AAA user/pw guide wiki:
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/AAA:Changing_Account_Passwords

Tim Rozet
Red Hat SDN Team

Yes, this sounds like the approach I would use.  In the past (downstream in
our BSC distribution), we used a script to spawn an h2 server process and
connect to that using psql / python.  The reason we abandoned that approach
was because we would need to do what you outlined here, and it was not
necessary for our use case.

Hope this helps!

On Tue, Nov 22, 2016 at 8:31 AM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Hi,

I'm glad Michael that you ask these questions, I give +1 to re-enable the
MD-SAL as the backend datastore for AAA. The issue for Bug4702 [0] it is
not there anymore since we moved to  blueprint, moreover using Md-SAL will
keep things in consistent ex: cluster use-case. Also one of the things that
it is really weird on the AAA design, we don't have a mechanism to switch
between the backend data store as we allow multiple datastores. Simply
after installing aaa-shiro feature if someone install aaa-mdsal or
aaa-casendra features this will screw the AAA service.

I give +1  for relying on shiro to  manage the authorization. For the
current role base authorization I believe it is enough and if we want to go
more and apply fine grant permission mechanisms for MD-SAL, we still can
leverage shiro for that.

Finally I believe, we should start deprecate the unused bundles in AAA. As
these bundles no body really contribute to it and they are not been used,
if we keep them, they will open a security threats for ODL.

[0] https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=4702

Thanks

On Tue, Nov 22, 2016 at 8:48 AM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Hello,

On Wed, Nov 23, 2016 at 3:57 AM, Mohamed ElSerngawy <melserngawy at inocybe.ca>
wrote:

I think this comes down to: is somebody willing to do the work to push us
to using the MD-SAL as our primary store?

--Colin


On Tue, Nov 22, 2016 at 11:58 PM, Mohamed ElSerngawy <melserngawy at inocybe.ca

It would require someone to not only ensure that it is functional, but
somewhat secure as well.  In short, we would have to restrict RESTCONF
access to those models on the northbound to the admin role, since only an
admin ought to have CRUD capability there (easy through shiro.ini).  That
still fails to address the fact that the models are still available via
MD-SAL java API(s), which would require some added critical thinking on how
to approach this.  A rogue application could somewhat easily grab the
DataBroker and extract a lot of "secure" information.  Maintaining an
encrypted shard may alleviate some of these concerns, but its not how
things are currently handled by that backend.

The fact is, this was added as a cool backend, but I don't think all of the
details were ever fully addressed due to several historical reasons.

Additionally, I'd be careful claiming that "blueprint fixes the loading
problem automatically"... I do believe there is a bit of extra work
required here in terms of expressing a RESTCONF dependency on AAA
IIDMService.  That said, I haven't ever really looked into solving this as
Brocade has taken the stance that ODL is not an Identity Provider, and that
existing well thought out software should be used.  If your view differs,
that is perfectly fine;  there is room for everyone's strategy :).

Again, I am not against it.  The issue that the MD-SAL based store is not
configurable actually has to deal with the translation from CSS to
blueprint;  in the past the backend was configurable through one of the
08-aaa-*.xml config files.  After that was removed, it is no longer able to
be configured.  I disliked this approach anyway, as Shiro provides the
Realm concept which is a more natural fit for what we are trying to do
anyway, and is injected at start time (highly configurable).

Hope this helps explain some of the history behind this.  I would agree
that using MD-SAL could be a better approach, but it isn't a trivial
problem due to the secure nature of AAA data.

BR,

Ryan Goulding

On Wed, Nov 30, 2016 at 7:53 AM, Muthukumaran K <muthukumaran.k at ericsson.com

If you are utilizing idmlight.db.mv.db (the TokenAuthRealm which is default
at this point), then yes you need to synchronize using OOB methods.  This
could be issuing identical rest requests to each node, or serving the file
based database on NAS.  It is similar to a local user store on a modern
networking switch in that it is considered unique per node.

To learn more, please consult the documentation [0].

Hi Michael,

This requirement has originally been raised by Tim Rozet, who needs this in the context of the ODL installer work he's doing e.g. for OPNFV, see also https://github.com/dfarrell07/puppet-opendaylight/issues/89. Basically, in that context, you want an "idempotent" way to create users and set passwords, scripted from an installer (with tools such as Puppet).
Coincidentally, I think the work I'm doing here will also "solve" https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=668 ... "solve" in quotes because, unless we do more work, there will still be a default uid/pwd created on first start by ODL - unless the IDM h2 DB already exists, created by this new CLI tool - without default uid/pwd (as outlined below; and OK'd by Ryan).

HTH.

Thanks

On Tue, Nov 22, 2016 at 8:31 AM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com<mailto:ryandgoulding at gmail.com>> wrote:
So if you FIRST run the tool, BEFORE ever starting Karaf (which creates the default user database with the default users, if there is none yet)

The SotreBuilder.init() method is only called if no store exists yet.  So we need to make sure to preserve the fact that if no store exists (i.e., you don't run the CLI tool first), then the database is still created as it always has been in the past.  People rely on those defaults.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Tue, Nov 22, 2016 at 8:28 AM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com<mailto:ryandgoulding at gmail.com>> wrote:
For now, for a first version, I propose to make it so that new users created by the new CLI tool automatically always get that 'user' role, and that you'll have to specify a new flag like "-a" ("--admin") if you would like the users being created to also have the 'admin' role. It wouldn't be possible to grant other roles.

Sounds reasonable.

If people actually use other roles than 'admin' and 'user' and it would be preferable to have options to set this more explicitly on the CLI options, then please shout.

Those are the default ones that were decided far before I got involved with the project.  At Brocade, we did not add any other custom roles and relied on the default 2.


Also, for security reasons, I would think that it would be wiser NOT to let this new CLI tool automatically create the default users which a current ODL out of the box installation has. So if you FIRST run the tool, BEFORE ever starting Karaf (which creates the default user database with the default users, if there is none yet), then your installation will not have those default users.

Sounds reasonable to me!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Tue, Nov 22, 2016 at 7:55 AM, Michael Vorburger <vorburger at redhat.com<mailto:vorburger at redhat.com>> wrote:
On Mon, Nov 21, 2016 at 8:17 PM, Tim Rozet <trozet at redhat.com<mailto:trozet at redhat.com>> wrote:

OK, thanks. Another requirement clarification kind of question:
I'm not crystal clear yet how flexible that business about "granting usernames specific permissions based on role? Don't we need the capability to be able to grant a username 'admin' level role/privileges?" from your -1 review comment on the WIP https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/48372/ needs to be...

For now, for a first version, I propose to make it so that new users created by the new CLI tool automatically always get that 'user' role, and that you'll have to specify a new flag like "-a" ("--admin") if you would like the users being created to also have the 'admin' role. It wouldn't be possible to grant other roles.
If people actually use other roles than 'admin' and 'user' and it would be preferable to have options to set this more explicitly on the CLI options, then please shout.

Also, for security reasons, I would think that it would be wiser NOT to let this new CLI tool automatically create the default users which a current ODL out of the box installation has. So if you FIRST run the tool, BEFORE ever starting Karaf (which creates the default user database with the default users, if there is none yet), then your installation will not have those default users.



Tim Rozet
Red Hat SDN Team

Hi All,

Lighting up this discussion again, I'm working on cleaning up AAA, removing
and deprecating unused code. I believe we should take decision on which
datastore we need to proceed with. There are two options:

1- Bring back MDSAL as the default datastore for AAA. Ryan was having
concern about that, I have initially try it and it looks fine but still
need to go through all test cases.
2- Provide a mechanism to switch between data stores. This will require a
massive changes to AAA bundles, services and features but it is not hard to
go there.

The question is: Do we really need to switch between data stores and
provide this option (ex: cluster ODL use mdsal and single ODL use H2) ? Or
we can just processed to bring MD-SAL again and stay with it ?

Thanks

On Wed, Nov 23, 2016 at 3:24 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Making it configurable should be relatively easy using the Shiro Realm idiom. We can discuss this tomorrow during our weekly meeting, and I can help provide insight on how to achieve it.

Sent from my iPhone
On 12/22/2016 10:57 AM, Amit Kumar wrote:

Hi,

Is there any way to provide resource specific access to different users?

In my use case, user A and B are using RESTCONF over NBI to access list
elements maintained in md-sal operational data store. This is the example
yang schema specific to my case.




*container X {  list L {    key "user"    leaf user {*


*      ...    }    leaf data {*



*      ...    }  }}*

Use case I am interested in is that, user A should be authorized to access
value (using RESTCONF) in "data" field only if list L's element is having
"user" field set with value 'A' (i.e. username of user A) and similarly
user B should be authorized to access value in "data" field only if list
L's element is having "user" field set with value 'B'.

Are there any ways to achieve such kind of controlled access, specifically
in pre-karaf helium release?

Thanks.

Regards,
Amit

Do you know if there is currently any interest in reviving that development and completing the integration with Keystone?

AAA was designed as a very modular system because each deployment scenario is going to demand different security constraints.  Integration with Keystone is not on the horizon for any active contributors to my knowledge, but it is something we are open to.  That said, one thing I would like to mention-- we had some guys from OPNFV upstream an OPNFV Moon authentication realm which integrates well with OpenStack from what I am told.  I have cc'd them if you have further questions.

Hope this helps!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20170123/a5a8b32e/attachment.html>

Hi Karthik,

In short, no this is not possible.  Internally, ODL stores password hashes,
not plaintext passwords, so the server side is locked down.  From the
client perspective, even if using basic authentication with Base64
username/password, the password is never stored (just read) for security
purposes.

Hope this helps.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

From: Ryan Goulding [mailto:ryandgoulding at gmail.com]
Sent: mercredi 25 janvier 2017 18:50
To: John Woods C
Cc: aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org; HE Ruan IMT/OLPS; BA Alioune OBS/OAB; Alioune; Jesus Javier Arauz
Subject: Re: [Aaa-dev] Integration of Keystone with AAA

Hi John,

Thanks for your interest in contributing to the AAA project.

I think it would initially be an AuthenticatingRealm, i.e. doing authentication only, and authorization could be added in a later contribution.

That is what I would recommend.  The advantage to using this approach includes the fact that AuthorizingRealm extends AuthenticatingRealm, so if/when you decide to add in the authorization piece, it is fairly easy to refactor.

Overall, the *Realm approach is the preferred method for adding new authentication mechanisms going forward, since they are easy to configure through shiro.ini for all sorts of different deployments.

How do you think we could approach this work?

Seems like you folks are already on the correct path.  Extending AuthenticatingRealm is fairly straightforward-- the interface is very well thought out and easy to use, thanks to the Apache Shiro folks upstream.

In Ericsson we are active in other ODL projects, such as SFC and Genius, but I don?t think we have contributed anything to AAA so far.

No worries-- we are open to contributions from anyone.  Feel free to reach out to the team via email/IRC and our weekly meeting.  One of the aims of AAA is to be adaptive to all different deployment cases, since people are using the controller in many different & interesting ways.  Thanks for your interest in contributing this new authentication mechanism.

Best Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Hi Ruan,

I am not much of an expert on authorization, but the way I see it is that the actual authorization mechanism / definition is something outside Keystone, so it can be implemented in different ways as long as it coherently processes the role vs. project information retrieved from Keystone. OpenStack services use policy.json files to define and verify authorization , but a service outside OpenStack, such as ODL AAA, could implement it differently.

Regards,
John

Subject: Re: [Aaa-dev] Integration of Keystone with AAA

Hi John,

Thanks for your interest in contributing to the AAA project.

I think it would initially be an AuthenticatingRealm, i.e. doing authentication only, and authorization could be added in a later contribution.

That is what I would recommend.  The advantage to using this approach includes the fact that AuthorizingRealm extends AuthenticatingRealm, so if/when you decide to add in the authorization piece, it is fairly easy to refactor.

Overall, the *Realm approach is the preferred method for adding new authentication mechanisms going forward, since they are easy to configure through shiro.ini for all sorts of different deployments.

How do you think we could approach this work?

Seems like you folks are already on the correct path.  Extending AuthenticatingRealm is fairly straightforward-- the interface is very well thought out and easy to use, thanks to the Apache Shiro folks upstream.

In Ericsson we are active in other ODL projects, such as SFC and Genius, but I don?t think we have contributed anything to AAA so far.

No worries-- we are open to contributions from anyone.  Feel free to reach out to the team via email/IRC and our weekly meeting.  One of the aims of AAA is to be adaptive to all different deployment cases, since people are using the controller in many different & interesting ways.  Thanks for your interest in contributing this new authentication mechanism.

Best Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Probably we would deliver verification based on user / password first.

This is a friendly remainder that your projects are still missing the M3
status. Please send your M3 status to release email list.

<Project Name>

Functionality Freeze:

1. Final list of externally consumable APIs defined: Yes/No
** If you had any Tentative APIs, have they been moved to Provisional or
Dropped? Yes/No (link to release plan)
** If any of your Tentative APIs were dropped, have you notified all
projects that were expecting them? Yes/No (link to e-mail)
** Also please list all dropped APIs.

2. Are all your inter-project dependencies resolved (i.e., have the other
projects you were counting on given you what you needed)? Yes/No
** If no, please list the features you were expecting that haven't been
delivered and the project you were expecting to receive them from.
** Note that you can only reasonably hold a project to something if you
formally asked for it during the release planning process and they
acknowledged that ask saying they would do it.

3. Were there any project-specific deliverables planned for this
milestone? Yes/No
** If so, were they delivered? Yes/No

Karaf Features Defined:

4. Are all your project's features that are intended for release added to
the features.xml and checked into the integration git repository? Yes/No
** (please provide link to features.xml)
** (please provide link to the gerrit patch that checks into the
integration git repository)

5. List all top-level, user-facing, and stable Karaf features for your
project.
** For top-level, user-facing, and stable Karaf features, please provide a
one-sentence description which a developer and/or user would find helpful.

Documentation:

6. List the kinds of documentation you will provide including at least:
** One user/operator guide section per user-facing feature.
** One developer guide per top-level feature.
** An installation guide for any top-level features that require more
than feature:install <feature-name> to install.
** Optional tutorials and how tos.

7. Have you checked in the AsciiDoc outlines to the docs repository? Yes/No
** (link to gerrit patch)

Integration and Test:

8. Have you started automated system testing for your top-level
features. Yes/No
** If yes, link to test report
** If no, why?

9. Have you filled out basic system test plan template [1] for each
top-level feature (karaf and not karaf) and a comprehensive system test
plan template including functionality, cluster, scalability, performance,
longevity/stability for each stable feature? Yes/No
** If yes, link to test plans
** If no, why?

Project Specific:

10. Have you updated your project facts with the project type
category? Yes/No
11. Do you acknowledge the changes to the RC Blocking Bug Policy for Carbon
Release [2]? Yes/No

On Fri, Feb 3, 2017 at 6:02 AM, David Suarez Fuentes <
david.suarez.fuentes at ericsson.com> wrote:

Hi David,

Pleasure to make your acquaintance.

I know the M4 has just passed


M4 is API freeze.  With something like this, you are really adding an
optional Realm implementation.  True, that impl may have some added API(s),
but we can seek a waiver on those if needed.  Because there are no
downstream dependencies, I don't see the harm in adding them past M4, but
we will need to seek agreement.

 the M5 is coming (03/02 - if I read correctly).


That is correct.

Are we on time to include it on Carbon?


RC0 for offset 0 is 4/13/2017... so we have a bit of runway between M4
(yesterday) and RC0 (when we can only merge blocking bugs).  I don't know
where your team stands on the implementation of this, but it would seem
there is still some time before we absolutely can't get the functionality
into the release.  If this is the case, we have two options:
1) Declare the bug blocking, and seek agreement to allow it into the
release from the release team.  This could be justified as a security
measure, since it improves the compatibility of ODL with outside systems.
2) Seek to add it in an SR, with the justification that it enhances ODL
security.

There are options going forward.  We will need to evaluate which one is
best as the implementation becomes solidified.

Hope this helps.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

There are options going forward.  We will need to evaluate which one is best as the implementation becomes solidified.

Hope this helps.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

From: miguel.angel.munoz.gonzalez at ericsson.com ( Miguel Angel Muñoz Gonzalez )
Text:
Hi everyone,
   I am checking documentation from aaa-cert since I would like to use certificate management service for adding TLS and securing ODL's northbound restconf interface (with jetty). By reading the documentation it seems that the Certificate Mgmt service can be used for two functions:  1. storing ODL certificate and 2. trust store to keep all switches (ext nodes) certificates. However, Can this also be used to secure RESTCONF so that jetty can take certificates from Certificate Manager and/or MDSAL directly?

I see that there are RPCs for:

-          Set/getNodeCertificate. I understand this is used for adding switches (ext nodes) certificates to the truststore.

-          Set/getODLCertificate: I guess this would be the place to store the certificate for securing jetty.

If it is possible to do this, do you know how jetty could take certificates from aaa-cert RPCs directly? As far as I know jetty is only capable of reading a local keystore that is setup in configuration. Plus, it has to be stopped and started everytime we change the configuration. Or is it a way to connect jetty with aaa-cert so that It can get certificates as they are added without restarting?

Thank you very much,
Best Regards,
Miguel ?ngel Mu?oz.

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20170207/970fc9a2/attachment.html>

Hi Miguel,

Can this also be used to secure RESTCONF so that jetty can take
certificates from Certificate Manager and/or MDSAL directly?

Yes, you can use certificate manager service to manage RestConf certificate
based auth. There are two mode of operations for the Certificate Manager
service:
1) Single ODL instance case, In this case Certificate manager service use
keystore files .jks that created under configuration/ssl/ directory  to
create self sign certificate and store the trusted certificate. So
basically you can use the configuration exist under [1] and point to the
same keystore.

2) Multi node Cluster ODL case, In this case Certificate manager service
store the keystores in MD-SAL. So you will need programmatically use the
ICertificateManager service and  create the SSLEngine object as the wiki
explained at [2]. I just did a quick search [3] I think it is possible but
it may need some work. OR we may find a way to export the keystores from
MDSAL to configuration/ssl/ directory then jetty can use it as the first
case.

Set/getNodeCertificate. I understand this is used for adding switches (ext
nodes) certificates to the truststore.
yes, you can use this also to store the certificates for securing jetty

Set/getODLCertificate: I guess this would be the place to store the
certificate for securing jetty.
Keep this only for ODL certificate and private key.

do you know how jetty could take certificates from aaa-cert RPCs directly?
I don't think this is possible. Jetty understand only keystore not
certificate string. You need to consume ICertificateManage service to get
the keystore.

Hope this could help, if you have anymore questions let me know.

Thanks

[1] https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/OpenDaylight_Controller:SSL_RestConf

[2]
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/AAA:How_to_use_the_Certificate_management_Service_to_manage_the_TLS_communication

[3]
https://examples.javacodegeeks.com/enterprise-java/jetty/jetty-ssl-configuration-example/

I will let Mohamed elaborate, but his cert framework was specifically
designed for southbound entity use case.  One cool thing though;  if you
have your etc/jetty.cfg set up correctly (i.e., with a confidentialPort),
you can actually enable TLS at runtime using org.ops4j.pax.web.cfg.  Those
properties are essentially owned by a ManagedService instance which will
make updates on the fly;  we do this with Brocade SDN Controller.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Wed, Feb 8, 2017 at 9:20 AM, Miguel Angel Mu?oz Gonzalez <
miguel.angel.munoz.gonzalez at ericsson.com> wrote:

Hi Migual,

  ODL certificate and private key (the one you configure with
set/getODLCertificate) what it is used for?
The certificate manager service by default generate selfsign certificate.
In the case the ODL need to sign its certificate request by CA, It should
first generate a certificate-Req then you can set the ODL certificate.
check the yang model at [1]. To be honest, I didn't see this in production
env till now. Usually in case of root CA signing, we setup the keystore
before packaging ODL and just include it. But the option is there for
future automated deployment.

Regards restart Jetty after updating the keystore
You can try Ryan advice, it will work. The main benefits you get from the
Certificate management service, is managing the keystore certificates
across all the TLS communication that ODL will establish. So you can use
the same Keystore with restconf Jetty connection instead of having multiple
keystore files in ODL.

We should find a way to point etc/jetty.xml SSL configuration to
odl-aaa-cert.xml configuration instead of modifying many config files.

[1]
https://github.com/opendaylight/aaa/blob/master/aaa-cert/src/main/yang/aaa-cert-rpc.yang#L45

Thanks

Hi everyone,

I am trying to set my own signed certificate (with a CA) based on a csr given by rpc aaa-cert-rpc:getODLCertificateReq.

After starting karaf first time, the loaded certificate is the one related to alias="controller" as stated in xml aaa-cert file (self-signed certificate by default). Then, I set my own signed certificate based on a csr given by rpc aaa-cert-rpc:getODLCertificateReq with rpc setODLCertifcate. It apparently works correctly. I can even put odl-keystore (by means of aaa-cert-mdals restconf) updating alias so that the related to my certificate is set (let's say "odl1"). Even if I invoke getODLCertificate rpc it returns my certificate (the one related to "odl1").
But, when I restart karaf (with or without clean option and debugging with -Djavax.net.debug=ssl,handshake), the "found key for : controller" log message shows the former alias "controller", karaf keeps loading the initial ODL self-signed certificate. Nevertheless, checking mdsal config for aaa-cert, I can see that everything stays as described above, this is, odl-kestore with both certificates and alias set to "odl1".
I performed several tests and I think that, no matter what alias field contains in odl-keystore, the first certificate in the encrypted keyfile is always the one loaded on ssl initialization. And that certificate can't be overwritten either deleted.
Testing without mdsal, provisioning keystore.jks file with keytool, I have no problem when removing the default odl self-signed certificate and adding my own one. I can even provisioning several certificates and they are all loaded when starting karaf:

found key for : odlserver
chain [0] = [
[
...
]
***
***
found key for : odl2
chain [0] = [
[

Any idea how to add a certificate signed with a CA and make karaf uses it (by means of mdsal)?

Best regards,

Ricardo Riolobos.

Hi Ricardo,

Just to clarify things, As I understand everything is working fine till you
restart ODL, then there are 2 scenarios:

1- if you are using (first option) keystore files that exist under
configuration/ssl/ to store the certificates then you need to update the
<alias> at aaa-cert-config.xml if you change it at runtime. ODL not update
the initial config xml files if you change the initial values at runtime.

2- if you are using (second option) MD-SAL to store the certificate. So
keep in mind that the initial config that exist at aaa-cert-config.xml will
be used only for the first time ODL start to create the keystores then all
the config will be stored at MD-SAL. Next time ODL start will read the
config that exist in MD-SAL not at aaa-cert-confg.xml. If that the case,
maybe the Certificate Manager service not updating the MD-SAL initial
config as you change the <alias> value at runtime to "odl1"

Would you confirm which scenario you have ? If I miss understand just give
kind of scenario steps to make things clear.

Thanks

Hi Mohamed and Ryan,

We debugged aaa-cert in order to find out why only the first ODL certificate is loaded on ssl initialization. Order has nothing to do. Following we try to describe our findings:

First of all, our signed certificates (based on ODL certificate requests and not self-signed) are not loaded by java class SunX509KeyManagerImpl because they are not a ?KeyEntry?.

On the other hand, ODL self-signed certificate generated by default is created and added to odl-keystore with PrivateKey:

Hi Ricardo,

Based on your finding there are two possibilities; 1- when you add signed
ODL certificate, you should add the CA certificate in both Trust and ODL
keystores, did you tried that? 2- You may try to have the signed
certificates and CA certificate only in the ODL-Keystore. there are
importSslDataKeystores and exportSslDataKeystores methods can help do this
if you are able to change the source code.  just try the first option.

we miss some rpc method to remove possible revoked certificates from both
odl-keystore and most importantly truststore keyfiles

In fact, There are some functions I'm planning to add them but just matter
of time. you can use aaa-cli command [1] there are commands can help.

Also feel free if you find a fix for that issue to push patch, we will
review and merge it.

Thanks

[1]
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/AAA:How_to_use_the_AAA_CLI_functionalities

Based on your finding there are two possibilities; 1- when you add signed ODL certificate, you should add the CA certificate in both Trust and ODL keystores, did you tried that? 2- You may try to have the signed certificates and CA certificate only in the ODL-Keystore. there are importSslDataKeystores and exportSslDataKeystores methods can help do this if you are able to change the source code.  just try the first option.

we miss some rpc method to remove possible revoked certificates from both odl-keystore and most importantly truststore keyfiles

In fact, There are some functions I'm planning to add them but just matter of time. you can use aaa-cli command [1] there are commands can help.

Also feel free if you find a fix for that issue to push patch, we will review and merge it.

Thanks

[1] https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/AAA:How_to_use_the_AAA_CLI_functionalities

Hi Mohamed and Ryan,

We debugged aaa-cert in order to find out why only the first ODL certificate is loaded on ssl initialization. Order has nothing to do. Following we try to describe our findings:

First of all, our signed certificates (based on ODL certificate requests and not self-signed) are not loaded by java class SunX509KeyManagerImpl because they are not a ?KeyEntry?.

On the other hand, ODL self-signed certificate generated by default is created and added to odl-keystore with PrivateKey:

On 02/16/2017 09:35 AM, David Suarez Fuentes wrote:

From: miguel.angel.munoz.gonzalez at ericsson.com ( Miguel Angel Muñoz Gonzalez )
Text:
Hi everyone,
Thanks for your help. Finally I have managed to get many things working. I leave my findings here to see if they match your expectations or in case it helps someone else.


-          Jetty only needs a file: keystore, to be able to handle its own certificate and trusted certificates from clients.



-          Jetty does not seem to use controllerTruststore properties in custom.properties file.

o   I managed to configure full HTTPS communication with client certificates and the only properties I had to set were OPS4J:

?  org.osgi.service.http.secure.enabled=true

?  org.ops4j.pax.web.ssl.keystore=configuration/ssl/.keystore

?  org.ops4j.pax.web.ssl.password=password

?  org.ops4j.pax.web.ssl.keypassword=password

?  org.ops4j.pax.web.ssl.clientauthneeded=true



-          Trusted certs can be added to keystore (no need to create a separated truststore file).

o   The only thing to be aware of is that the entry type in the keystore for these trusted certs has to be different: Instead of PrivateKeyEntry they have to be Trusted entry)

o   Note there are three types in a keystore are: PrivateKey, Trusted and Secret.



-          During ODL execution it is possible to update the keystore. I found a mechanism to restart Jetty without restarting ODL. Just restart Jetty bundle:

o   bundle:restart -f $(bundle:id "OPS4J Pax Web - Jetty")



-          Using client certificates works perfectly well for RestConf. I added the client's self-signed certificate to the keystore (as trusted entry) and worked fine. As an interesting fact, if I add the same certificate as PrivateKey entry, it works as well.

I am planning on adding a number of test cases to csit covering this behaviour. I will send a separate mail to start a discussion.
Any thoughts?

Thanks everyone for your help on this matter,
Best Regards,
Miguel ?ngel Mu?oz.

From: miguel.angel.munoz.gonzalez at ericsson.com ( Miguel Angel Muñoz Gonzalez )
Text:
Hi everyone,
 As mentioned in the previous mail I would like to add some tests to aaa project to show some basic HTTPS/TLS communication in RESTCONF, using also client certificates. The purpose is also to write down the steps needed to configure ODL as secure server (documented as a set of working test cases).

The tests would be something like:

Test secure RESTCONF request, using server's certificate
Test secure RESTCONF request, using server's certificate and client certificate
Repeat above items with a request for Jolokia data (e.g. cluster mbeans)
If previous items were done with self-signed certificates, then repeat with CA signed certificates
Additionally I could include some tests with revocation lists.

They would be intended for clustered environment, thus I would need to handle the keystore directly with keytool across every node in the cluster.
Would you consider it as a proper contribution?

Best Regards,
Miguel ?ngel Mu?oz.

Hi,

I am working on some changes in the ODL AAA module to permit authentication using OpenStack Keystone as an external identity provider backend. To have a tighter integration with OpenStack I would like the networking-odl driver to automatically forward credentials in RESTCONF petitions to ODL instead of the operator having to explicitly configure separate user credentials to be sent.

My idea is that networking-odl driver could receive and forward in the RESTCONF, user credentials or token that came in the triggering petition to Neutron, or maybe the credentials or token related to the Neutron service user itself.  Do you think this is feasible to do in networking-odl driver? Is it somehow possible already or would it be a lot of work? Would it require any changes in Neutron itself, or just in the ODL driver?

Thanks a lot,
John

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20170223/4d5b5a65/attachment-0001.html>

Just FYI, we are starting to dissuade the use of shiro.ini to write
authorization rules.  In general, shiro.ini will eventually die, but it
will take a few release cycles.  This was discussed with Mike V. and others
on the last Kernel Projects call-- shiro.ini was useful to get Shiro based
concepts in for JSF, but it is not a good long term solution as it is not
cluster aware and not really SOA.  If you extract the correct roles in
doGetAuthorizationInfo for your AuthorizingRealm, you can use an even more
modern approach I introduced here:

https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/50694/

This allows you to define RBAC rules for HTTP in the more traditional model
based approached, and is more future proof.  My apologies for missing the
meeting, if you have questions, feel free to reach out to me on IRC or
email.

HTH


Regards,

Ryan Goulding

An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20170224/c729ed54/attachment.html>

The new model based approach should be a lot easier to maintain from an end
user perspective since it will have the automatic restconf/netconf
bindings.  You can use it today in Carbon (working on a back port to
Boron), and the only difference between it and shiro.ini impl is that the
url pattern is relative to "/" instead of the individual servlet context.
For example, while using shiro.ini and locking down streams, you would use
url pattern "/streams/**".  With the new approach, you use the url pattern
"/restconf/streams/**".  shiro chooses to do things relative to the servlet
context as it greatly simplifies some of the authorization logic on their
side (especially when using annotation based authz).   If you want a demo
of how this works, I am more than happy to jump on a webex with you folks
at some point.

Best,

Ryan Goulding

An HTML attachment was scrubbed...

Hi Om,

api doc explorer is actually part of the netconf project, so +netconf-dev.

The api doc explorer will still enumerate every single API assuming correct
credentials are provided.  That is the way it was written, and it was not
my choice.  However, you can restrict which roles can actually execute
those API commands (they will still appear in the web page though!).  As of
Carbon release, you can achieve this sort of Authorization through using
the "aaa" model and accompanying MDSALDynamicAuthorizationFilter (enabled
on RESTCONF by default).  Information on the aaa model can be found in the
README [0] under MDSALDynamicAuthorizationFilter and will also be added to
our proper documentation prior to the Carbon release.

Notes on LDAP integration are already included here [1] under
ODLJndiLdapRealm.

Hope this helps!

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

[0] https://github.com/opendaylight/aaa/blob/master/README.md
[1]
https://github.com/opendaylight/docs/blob/master/docs/user-guide/authentication-and-authorization-services.rst

From: Ryan Goulding [mailto:ryandgoulding at gmail.com<mailto:ryandgoulding at gmail.com>]
Sent: jueves, 23 de febrero de 2017 19:58
To: John Woods C <john.c.woods at ericsson.com<mailto:john.c.woods at ericsson.com>>
Cc: aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org<mailto:aaa-dev at lists.opendaylight.org>
Subject: Re: [Aaa-dev] proposal for AAA Authorization with Keystone

Just FYI, we are starting to dissuade the use of shiro.ini to write authorization rules.  In general, shiro.ini will eventually die, but it will take a few release cycles.  This was discussed with Mike V. and others on the last Kernel Projects call-- shiro.ini was useful to get Shiro based concepts in for JSF, but it is not a good long term solution as it is not cluster aware and not really SOA.  If you extract the correct roles in doGetAuthorizationInfo for your AuthorizingRealm, you can use an even more modern approach I introduced here:

https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/50694/

This allows you to define RBAC rules for HTTP in the more traditional model based approached, and is more future proof.  My apologies for missing the meeting, if you have questions, feel free to reach out to me on IRC or email.

HTH


Regards,

Ryan Goulding

other exception you are seeing is a bug that we are aware of, but haven't
filed yet.  I cannot reproduce the bug locally but have seen it on Jenkins,
and am querying Stephen Kitt for some guidance as it has to do with karaf4
migration.

Ryan Goulding

On 19 April 2017 at 16:54, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com<mailto:ryandgoulding at gmail.com>> wrote:
I would like to improve the Moon driver realm but the code in  aaa-shiro/impl/ is no longer appearing in eclipse (project explorer) with the new hierarchy of AAA and that makes difficult to add  new code

I am not familiar with eclipse import procedures.  The issue is likely that the package naming doesn't contain impl.  This was done on purpose, as when we moved to archetype setup we didn't update the packages.  That is because for some long historical reasons, downstream dependencies would need to be updated too.  That is a lot of work and not suited for pre release activity.

I also observe that karaf debugging mode fails to a few seconds after ?./bin/karaf debug?.

Is there an error message?  Not really giving us much to go on here...

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Wed, Apr 26, 2017 at 3:15 PM Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Hi Colin,

You are not suppose to use them after the changes that we made in the
patch. Basically these functionalities were there because of the keystores
need to be generated after starting ODL. But now, the keystore will be
created once you install the aaa-cert feature. keeping this functionalities
could make a serious security thread.

BR

Hi Luis,

I test the aa-cert RPCs with Boron and it works fine, did u change the
aaa-cert-config.xml file ? I guess you may missed that. basically you need
to change the <use-config> to true if you want to use keystore files and
change <use-mdsal> true if you want to store  the keystores in mdsal. Then
don't forget to restart karaf. check the wiki for more info

[0]
https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/AAA:How_to_use_the_Certificate_management_Service_to_manage_the_TLS_communication

Hi Colin,

Can we get documentation for how somebody is supposed to:
1.) create the ODK keystore and trust keystore (replacing gen-odl-ks and
gen-trust-ks)
yes, just after installing the aaa-cert feature and changing the
aaa-cert-config the keystore will be created. You can also use the java
keytool commands to create the keystore instead. Moreover, If you wish to
use a pre-created keystores signed by CA just copy those files to
 directory configuration/ssl/ and change the aaa-cert-config.xml
<use-config> to true  odl will use those files

2.) add a certificate to the ODL and turst keystores (replacing
add-odl-cert and add-trust-cert)
use the RPCs to do this.

BR

On Thu, Apr 27, 2017 at 11:46 AM, Colin Dixon <colin at colindixon.com> wrote:

I admittedly missed this configuration as well!

Sent from my iPhone

Thanks Mohamed, it works in Boron with your suggestion.

So what happens is that in Boron both <use-config> and <use-mdsal> are set to false by default and as a minimum you need to set the first to true for the feature to work. In Carbon both are set to true by default so the feature works out-of-the-box.

BR/Luis

Hello AAA devs.

I have a question, originally mentioned as a comment
in a Bug ... I am unable to locate right now.

Anyway, it is related to various bugs
such as 7792 [1] and 8209 [2].
As more specific symptoms (8214 [3], 8062 [4])
are fixed now, I begin to suspect the 401 status
is actually expected from an isolated cluster member.

I think AAA is storing some data to mdsal datastore,
which is of course inaccessible on minority partition.

but 401 is fine as long as it gets documented.

We will update suites to expect the agreed upon response.

Vratko.

On 05/04/2017 01:00 PM, Ryan Goulding wrote:

I will also note that it is not entirely useful at the moment to derive
multiple tenants.  This was an aspect of the data model that original
contributors added, but never quite put their heads around.  We have kept
it for compatibility purposes, but just recommend using "sdn".  I.e.,
network segmentation over RESTCONF is something that you are better off
using "roles" for instead of "tenants".  In nitrogen, we hope to improve
this OOB.  Right now, the only difference will primarily be in logging for
tenants.  Not particularly great but wasn't a priority to fix fin the past.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Hi Jamo et al.,

Just to continue this thread in case anyone is ever looking through
archives, I have proposed a fix here [0].  Since ids should be considered
an internal detail, I repeated the checks for all other aspects of the AAA
data store (grantid, userid, roleid, domainid).  In the case that someone
does specify an id, a 400 HTTP error message is returned to the client,
since the client request is flawed.  Does this seem like a good approach?

For reference, we are hoping to migrate to an OOB MDSAL based store in
Nitrogen.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Hi aaa-devs,

I am currently working out the addition of an optional new MD-SAL ODLAuthorizingRealm.  For those not familiar with AAA abstractions, Realms are configurable (currently through shiro.ini), and no one actually needs to use this new realm (fully backwards compatible).  However, based on community feedback, I know several people are interested.  I have uploaded a patch with my current API thoughts [0];  I would like to invite anyone who has interest in using this to provide feedback so that we can nail down a great API.  Please be harsh now, as it is hard to change later!

Best Regards,

Ryan Goulding

 As mentioned in the previous mail I would like to add some tests to aaa project to show some basic HTTPS/TLS communication in RESTCONF, using also client certificates. The purpose is also to write down the steps needed to configure ODL as secure server (documented as a set of working test cases).

The tests would be something like:

Test secure RESTCONF request, using server?s certificate
Test secure RESTCONF request, using server?s certificate and client certificate
Repeat above items with a request for Jolokia data (e.g. cluster mbeans)
If previous items were done with self-signed certificates, then repeat with CA signed certificates
Additionally I could include some tests with revocation lists.

They would be intended for clustered environment, thus I would need to handle the keystore directly with keytool across every node in the cluster.
Would you consider it as a proper contribution?

Best Regards,
Miguel ?ngel Mu?oz.

Hi


As a part of Brocade, we had committed some code for Callhome in netconf project few months back. As a part of the review, some utilities were identified to be a part of AAA service since these could be used generically across projects. Also, now we may need these utilities as a part of different effort in netconf project.

These utilities basically provide conversion of Public and private keys to Strings and from Strings to public/private kay pairs.


In an effort to appropriately place the code and have proper dependencies, i have restructured the code and made it a part of aaa-encryption service.

Test code has also been committed for these.


Patch URL: https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/58452/


Please take a look at this patch and let me know if there are any comments.


Thanks

Atul

Hi oltu devs,

My name is Ryan Goulding, and I am a Project Lead on ODL, an open source SDN platform.  We depend on oltu for oauth2 implementation in our AAA implementation.  However, one of the issues we are currently running into is the controversial nature surrounding the org.json/json license that includes the famous ?do no evil? clause.  It appears that you utilize org.json [0] despite the controversial license.  Is there any plan to move away from org.json in the future, or is this something you plan to stick with for the foreseeable future?  Would be great to hear back from you so we can decide how to proceed, since our aim is to remove org.json/json from ODL in our next release.

Thanks and best regards!
Ryan Goulding

[0] https://github.com/apache/oltu/blob/trunk/commons/json/pom.xml#L35-L39 <https://github.com/apache/oltu/blob/trunk/commons/json/pom.xml#L35-L39>

On Wed, Jul 5, 2017 at 10:51 AM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

Well yeah - depends on what ?supported? means.    Most SP customers tend to deploy on the most stable release of any given platform that they can find (of those which have the features they need), and don?t tend to upgrade for a while (where ?a while? may be years).

so I?d expect any vendors offering commercial ODL distros to be very much supporting Boron at this stage - even if there will never be another SR.  And yes - I?d hope in the open-source world that we still answer queries and still occasionally merge into stable/boron.

at any rate it?s probably time I updated all my postman collections etc. to Carbon - the key pain-point there is the deprecation of the config API for BGP in favour of OpenConfig.

Ack... I agree and can sympathize with the pain behind doing major version
upgrades of products.  I have spent several weekends migrating this
software in my lifetime :), and I am sure others on here have too.

Most downstream vendors I have worked for maintain a self-supported
stability branch to do releases past what is supported upstream, but I do
want to point out that staying as up to date as possible is best suggested
practice.



Regards,

Ryan Goulding

I'm on PTO at the moment, so I'll read through this in some more detail
later, but wanted to chime in now to say that the TSC agreed a long time
ago to support bug fixes in service releases for the previous release,
e.g., Carbon while working toward releasing Nitrogen, and then off-cycle
releases for security issues as needed for the privous two releases, e.g.,
Boron and Carbon while working toward releasing Nitrogen.

This isn't a limit saying that we can'd do other things or that we can't
still support them by helping with questions, but it's a statement of the
minimum level of support we agree to provide to our releases. That being
said, we have typically not had the gratuitious resources to provide heavy
support for older releases and typically the community has had waning
interest in fixing issues in releases older that 1-2 back. That being said,
we're maturing as a community and platform, so the massive differences
between releases have been somewhat less pronounced recently. We could
re-evaluate it if need be.

--Colin

Hi,

odlparent 2.0.2 has been released. The changes since 2.0.1 are as
follows:
* https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/59932 ? ensure script permissions
  are correct (https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=8798)
* https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/59939 ? preserve our patches in
  the final Karaf distribution
  (https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=8799)
* https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/59837 ? disable SFT on feature
  repositories by default

odlparent 2.0.2 is once again capable of producing a working
distribution, unlike 2.0.1 (sorry!). It has passed CSIT on NetVirt, and
a round of local testing.

The only blocking issues fixed in this release affect karaf4-parent, so
the upgrade requirements are minimal:
* integration/distribution needs to upgrade to 2.0.2
* all project modules inheriting from karaf4-parent and currently using
  2.0.1 need to upgrade to 2.0.2

Apart from that, most projects are free to upgrade as they wish; the
exceptions are aaa and netconf which need to upgrade to at least 2.0.1
to ensure the Bouncy Castle dependencies are coherent. But I would
strongly encourage all projects to upgrade to 2.0.2 at their earliest
convenience.

(I have tested various mixed configurations with no issue, including
Robert?s proposed test using restconf with a 2.0.2 dependency and
bgpcep with a 2.0.1 dependency, and simultaneously loading features.)

Regards,

-- 
Stephen Kitt
Principal Software Engineer, Office of Technology
Red Hat

this in more details.

On Thu, Jul 20, 2017 at 12:24 AM, Colin Dixon <colin at colindixon.com> wrote:

It fixes it in a bandaid sort of way... the correct solution is to move to
Jersey 2 so that jersey instantiates these objects through java code and
not web.xml at runtime.  Then we can do correct bean instantiation and
wiring.  There is a separate stopgap I was investigating through using a
web.xml Listener but it appears that doesn't work.  This at least gets us
over the initial bug, but the long term solution is to use Jersey 2.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

How to install Keystone in Docker
# pull the keystone docker image
docker pull clearlinux/keystone
 
# set a couple of useful env. vars 
YOUR_HOST=`hostname -f`
MYSQL_DATA_DIR=/var/lib/mysql/
 
# generate certificates 
CERT_PATH=`pwd`
CERT_NAME=keystone_cert
openssl req -x509 -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout keystone_key.pem \
    -out $CERT_NAME.pem -subj "/CN=$YOUR_HOST"
 
# start the container 
docker run -d -it --name keystone -p 5000:5000 -p 35357:35357 \
       -h $YOUR_HOST \
       -e IDENTITY_HOST="$YOUR_HOST" \
       -e KEYSTONE_ADMIN_PASSWORD="secret" \
       -v $MYSQL_DATA_DIR:/var/lib/mysql \
       -v `pwd`/keystone_cert.pem:/etc/nginx/ssl/keystone_cert.pem \
       -v `pwd`/keystone_key.pem:/etc/nginx/ssl/keystone_key.pem \
       clearlinux/keystone
 
# login into keystone container 
docker exec -it keystone bash
 
# inside the container must set the environment 
source openrc
openstack user list
 
# create user CSC_user
openstack user create --password cscuser CSC_user
 
# create project (tenant)
openstack project create --description "CSC Project" CSC_project
 
# assign the user to the project
openstack user set --project CSC_project CSC_user
 
# create role CSC_admin
openstack role create CSC_admin
 
# user access to project requires a specific role
openstack role add --project CSC_project --user CSC_user CSC_admin
 
# create a service 
openstack service create --name CSC --description "Serves all NBI interactions with CSC" CSC_type
 
# create service endpoints for a given service 
openstack endpoint create CSC_type admin https://CSC:35357/v3
openstack endpoint create CSC_type public https://CSC:5000/v3
HowTo add the certificate to the keystore
CERT=${CERT_PATH}/${CERT_NAME}.pem
 
# import the certificate
sudo keytool -import -alias keystone_cert -file $CERT -keystore $JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/security/cacerts -storepass changeit
 
# delete the certificate from the JVM cacerts
sudo keytool -delete -alias keystone_cert -keystore /usr/lib/jvm/java-8-oracle/jre/lib/security/cacerts -storepass changeit
HowTo provision the keystore
Postman Collection for CRUD operations in Domain, Project, User and Token:
https://www.getpostman.com/collections/cbd22b040b3da8affa68
nginx config files
HTTP config file
HTTPS server side auth config file
HTTPS mutual auth config file
To reload the nginx config execute the command below - within the container

# reload the nginx config
nginx -s reload
HowTo launch test cases when committing a patch in Gerrit
If you want to launch aaa tests when committing aaa code patches just include following keywords in the comment section of Gerrit:
 
?	?test-aaa-authn? will launch aaa-csit-1node-authn-all-{stream} job
?	?test-aaa-keystone? will launch aaa-csit-1node-keystone-all-{stream} job
HowTo Execute Keystore Authentication Test Cases
*********************************************************
ODL CONTROLLER
*********************************************************
# Get ODL AAA code and compile
git clone ssh://{username}@git.opendaylight.org:29418/aaa.git
cd aaa
mvn clean install -DskipTests=true -Dcheckstyle.skip=true
 
# Start ODL and install aaa feature
opendaylight-user at root>feature:install odl-restconf-all
 
# Set AAA log level to TRACE
opendaylight-user at root>log:set TRACE org.opendaylight.aaa
 
# Set below parameter values in ~/aaa/karaf/target/assembly/etc/shiro.ini file:
keystoneAuthRealm = org.opendaylight.aaa.shiro.realm.KeystoneAuthRealm
keystoneAuthRealm.keystoneServerURL = https://eceujmm-virtualbox:35357
keystoneAuthRealm.sslVerification = true
securityManager.realms = $tokenAuthRealm, $keystoneAuthRealm
 
# Set below parameter values in ~/aaa/karaf/target/assembly/etc/opendaylight/datastore/initial/config/aaa-cert-config.xml file:
<use-config>true</use-config>
<tls-protocols>TLSv1.2</tls-protocols>
 
# Stop ODL
 
# Start ODL without "clean" option
 
*********************************************************
ROBOT
*********************************************************
# Get ODL Integration/test code
git clone ssh://${ODL_USERNAME}@git.opendaylight.org:29418/integration/test.git
 
# Get commit
https://git.opendaylight.org/gerrit/#/c/52066/
 
# Start RIDE
ride.py
 
# In the "Run" tab define following arguments
e exclude -v USER_HOME:$HOME -v ODL_SYSTEM_IP:172.28.128.3 -v ODL_SYSTEM_USER:eceujmm  -v ODL_SYSTEM_PROMPT:$ -v DEFAULT_LINUX_PROMPT:$ -v TOOLS_SYSTEM_IP:127.0.0.1 -v TOOLS_SYSTEM_USER:eceujmm -v TOOLS_SYSTEM_PASSWORD:ujmmece -v TOOLS_SYSTEM_NAME:localhost
 
# Run the test case
Dynamic authorization
In order to use the dynamic authorization module, shiro has to be properly configured - which, by default, it already is. Just make sure you have the following lines uncommented:

dynamicAuthorization = org.opendaylight.aaa.shiro.realm.MDSALDynamicAuthorizationFilter
# ...
/** = authcBasic, dynamicAuthorization
This activates the dynamic authz filter. By default, if no policies are provisioned, everyone has access to all resources.

To provision an authz policy into ODL, use the following REST end-point

 PUT /config/aaa:http-authorization
 {
   "aaa:http-authorization": {
     "aaa:policies": {
       "aaa:policies": [
         {
           "aaa:resource": "/**",
           "aaa:permissions": [
             {
               "aaa:role": "admin",
               "aaa:actions": [
                 "get",
                 "delete",
                 "put",
                 "post"
               ]
             }
           ]
         }
       ]
     }
   }
 }
The aforementioned policy will grant access to any resource for users having the admin role, for the POST / PUT / GET / DELETE HTTP methods. The method list is inclusive - meaning that the user will lose access to any method not specified within the method list.

Dear developers of the OpenDaylight project,

my name is Lea Gr?ber. I am a researcher in computer science at Saarland University, Germany. My group is currently conducting a user study to investigate the usability of security libraries. 

We figured out that you use odl-aaa-encryption-service as a security library in https://github.com/opendaylight/aaa <https://github.com/opendaylight/aaa>.  
We would be very interested in the reasons why you decided for this specific library and did not choose a different one. 
Therefore, we would like to invite the developers who worked with this lib and were involved in the decision to participate in a brief interview on the phone, on Skype or slack.

In principle I am interested in any security-relevant library you might have worked with. It does not have to be in a special project or programming language.
If you worked with other security libs, those are equally relevant for this study. (In general a security-relevant library is a lib, that solves a security related programming task for you, e.g. authentication, signing or encryption - or just the generation of a secure hash value).

If participating in this line of research sounds interesting to you and you would like to support my current work, please contact me either via email, Skype or Slack:

Skype: leagroeber
Slack: https://join.slack.com/t/cs-study-participant/shared_invite/MjI4MTAwMzc1MjM1LTE1MDI5OTc1ODEtMjdmOTE1MTY4Mg <https://join.slack.com/t/cs-study-participant/shared_invite/MjI4MTAwMzc1MjM1LTE1MDI5OTc1ODEtMjdmOTE1MTY4Mg>
E-Mail: lgroeber at mmci.uni-saarland.de <mailto:lgroeber at mmci.uni-saarland.de>

Thank you very much for considering my request! I appreciate your help :)

Best, 

Lea

Subject: Re: [controller-dev] [OpenDaylight TSC] Nitrogen RC1 Build CSIT Failures

Netvirt has a lot of problems, mostly all due to the same (assuming) clustering issues we saw in carbon. I think those are mostly resolved now with hard work from people like Sam, Robert and Tom. But, I don't think those changes were merged in nitrogen when the autorelease job ran which triggered these tests.

We need a respin, I think.

If not that, I can file some blocker bug(s) for us to track the problems we see in the netvirt CSIT.

Thanks,
JamO

Hi Lori

This comes as a result of a certain enhancements done during Carbon SR1 for
netconf password encryption. If the password is not encrypted, the code
still tries to decrypt and though it doesnt impact anything and same
password is used, an exception is thrown from AAA module on this. It
couldnt be curtailed during that time because change in AAA was impacting
some downstream projects. It should not the case with releases after Carbon
SR1. If not, please file a bug to show a warning here instead of error.

Thanks
Atul

Hello Oxygen Projects,

This is a repeat of last week's reminder.

This is a friendly reminder for the 17 projects below to complete their M1
milestone status readout as soon as possible as it is past due more than 10
days and M2 milestone status due date is impending:

   - aaa
   - coe
   - dlux
   - dluxapps
   - infrautils
   - mdsal
   - ocpplugin
   - of-config
   - openflowplugin
   - opflex
   - p4plugin
   - packetcable
   - snmp
   - sxp
   - tsdr
   - unimgr
   - yangtools


As communicated earlier, milestone status needs to be submitted as
reStructuredText file (similar to release notes) into the docs project -
see Section 4, item aa in TSC meeting minutes [1].   All submitted and
merged milestone readouts can be viewed here to make them readily
accessible [2] - note that we have converted the M0 emails, where
applicable, into rst files for all the participating projects.

Please make a copy of the m1 status template file [3], update, and submit
your milestone readout into this folder of the docs project:
"docs/release-process/milestone-readouts/m1".

There is a useful online reStructuredText tool [4] you can use to validate
your rst file contents - copy the rst file contents into the left pane and
you will see the rendered HTML on the right pane.  If your rst file checkin
fails verification, it will likely be failing the tox coala check.  Please
look for the tox-coala.log.gz file in the build log for details.

For the 20+ projects that have submitted their m1 status and merged - Thank
you!  Please feel free to use them as references.

Best Regards,
Kit Lou

Hi everyone:


I am trying to get started with aaa source code and in particular its authorization. I got the code from here:

According to the README.md, AAA is automatically installed upon installation of odl-restconf-noauth and enabled through aaa-shiro-act, but after I built the code and launch karaf, there is no such features in its feature:list. I try to add netconf features repo from ODL Carbon release but odl-restconf-* still cannot be installed (error occurs).


I manually installed odl-aaa-shiro and was able to test the authentication example provided in README.md. However, the authorization example requires restconf as well.

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/aaa-dev/attachments/20171121/9d7dd469/attachment.html>

Thats because aaa doesn't include/depend on the RESTCONF related features,
it is the other way around.  To get RESTCONF from aaa karaf shell you will
need to do a feature:repo-add on the appropriate RESTCONF feature
repository then install odl-restconf.

Hope this helps,

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

On Tue, Dec 12, 2017 at 2:19 PM, Ryan Goulding <ryandgoulding at gmail.com>
wrote:

How are the features being installed? I am asking because since karaf 4 we do not support successive feature installation from karaf console as this can cause bundle restart and that is something most projects in ODL cannot handle today. I am not sure there is a release note for this but the workaround is to either: 1) use --no-auto-refresh in the consecutive feature install command as Michael points out, 2) list all the features you need in the karaf config boot file or 3) install all features at once in console, for example:

feature:install odl-restconf odl-netconf-mdsal odl-mdsal-apidocs odl-clustering-test-app odl-netconf-topology

BR/Luis

Subject: Re: [Aaa-dev] ComponentDefinitionException: Error when instantiating bean provider of class org.opendaylight.aaa.impl.AAAShiroProvider

How are the features being installed? I am asking because since karaf 4 we do not support successive feature installation from karaf console as this can cause bundle restart and that is something most projects in ODL cannot handle today. I am not sure there is a release note for this but the workaround is to either: 1) use --no-auto-refresh in the consecutive feature install command as Michael points out, 2) list all the features you need in the karaf config boot file or 3) install all features at once in console, for example:

feature:install odl-restconf odl-netconf-mdsal odl-mdsal-apidocs odl-clustering-test-app odl-netconf-topology

BR/Luis

Rajarajan,

double check "feature:list -i" (listing installed features) after you install
odl-netvirt-openstack. you are probably getting the restconf feature installed
for you as it's a per-requisite for netvirt-openstack.

JamO

This code is actually not AAA specific... org.ops4j.pax.web.cfg is laid
down by karaf, which is provided by odlparent, so adding in that mailing
list.

It looks like you aren't following those instructions quite based on the
fact that your files seem to be very different from what the wiki steps
state.  Are you modifying them in some way?

But SSL RESTCONF connection is not opening


What do you receive for a response code?  Or do you not receive on at all?
In the latter case, it would imply that something isn't configured
correctly in the jetty.xml file.  I'd suggest turning on logging and taking
a look at what happens when you install "odl-mdsal-apidocs".  If the
"addConnector" directive is incorrect, the secure port won't ever be opened.

Hope this helps.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

This code is actually not AAA specific... org.ops4j.pax.web.cfg is laid down by karaf, which is provided by odlparent, so adding in that mailing list.

It looks like you aren't following those instructions quite based on the fact that your files seem to be very different from what the wiki steps state.  Are you modifying them in some way?

But SSL RESTCONF connection is not opening

What do you receive for a response code?  Or do you not receive on at all?  In the latter case, it would imply that something isn't configured correctly in the jetty.xml file.  I'd suggest turning on logging and taking a look at what happens when you install "odl-mdsal-apidocs".  If the "addConnector" directive is incorrect, the secure port won't ever be opened.

Hope this helps.

Regards,

Ryan Goulding

Thanks Evan ?

It?s working after making below changes in C:\master\distribution\karaf\target\assembly\etc\org.ops4j.pax.web

javax.servlet.context.tempdir = data/pax-web-jsp
org.ops4j.pax.web.config.file = etc/jetty.xml
org.osgi.service.http.port = 8181

org.osgi.service.http.secure.enabled=true
org.osgi.service.http.port.secure=8443
org.ops4j.pax.web.ssl.keystore=configuration/ssl/.keystore
org.ops4j.pax.web.ssl.password=123456
org.ops4j.pax.web.ssl.keypassword=123456

Note that etc\jetty.xml and etc\custom.properties remains untouched.

expected?

Hi Vamsi,

I have faced this same error a long time ago (not in Nitrogen though), 
but at the time I wasn't able to figure out the root cause. Which ODL 
version are you using? Nitrogen SR1?

Have you tried cleaning OpenDaylight and restarting the service? I 
usually follow this procedure (in CentOS):

/rm -rf <odl_folder>/data/ <odl_folder>/journal/ <odl_folder>/instances//

and then:

/systemctl restart opendaylight.service/

Afterwards, please check karaf.log and wait until ODL has finished booting.

If this does not solve the problem, I don't know what else you could do. 
Maybe this thread should be moved to a more related mailing list.

Does anyone know what could be the reason of ODL stuck with "Deploying"?

Best regards,
Ignacio.
